He crossed his arms, and a tiny smile spread across his lips. "You're well versed in this, aren't you? Just want to cut to the chase?"</p> <p>"So who is it? Who's your augur?" Although there might be home-spun hierarchies in a large church with many attendees, the main distinction was very simple. The foundation was the devotees, many in number, who worshipped and sacrificed and gave their tithes. The pillars upon that foundation, the ministers- like Levi, apparently. They arranged services, advised their followers. And above them, there were the augurs. They emerged from their charnel-houses and radio sanctuaries only masked in cloth. Over long sleepless nights they would pray to their saints, commune with the cosmic background that enshrined them. Ministers handled the administration of the church, but it was the augurs who guided their hands.</p> <<else>>\ <p>Levi crossed his arms. "I am a humble shepherd. I don't claim to lead anyone, only show them the direction that the living god wants for them."</p> <p>"The 'living god.' Yes. That person. Who are they?" This was just dripping with cult vibes.</p> <</if>>\ <p>"My augur, my god. The resurrected saint." His entire demeanour changed as he spoke of this person. He was almost choking up, just saying the words. "Their identity isn't important. They are... in hiding, due to the political situation. As am I, but as a holy figure they have been more affected by this than any of us."</p> <p>Of course. "So you're saying I can't meet whoever I'm ostensibly working for."</p> <p>"You are working for me. And that's as much as I'm willing to say to an outsider about our church at the moment. Like I said, the political situation surrounding us is... sensitive."</p> * [[“I assume that has something to do with the theft.”|Cross Theft]]<p>Here it was. The part where he got to the cult shit. "What exactly is //different// about you?"</p> <p>"Our patron saint is one that isn't venerated in the churches up North. They serve as our augur."</p> <p>//Serve,// present tense. If there was one thing that was true about every saint, shot, hanged, burned, flayed alive, it's that they were all dead. D-E-A-D dead. <<if $identity.includes("devotee")>>In fact, the idea of one being both a saint and an augur was nonsense. A saint was a plug, an augur was a socket.<<else>>They didn't exactly go into the grisly details when you attended the church as a child, but everybody knows that saints are dead. Even you.<</if>></p> * [[“I'm sorry, how can they be a saint if they're alive?”|Cross Sainthood]] * [[“So who's your cult leader, huh?”|Cross Cult Leader]]<p>Levi lit up. He tilted his hat down a little as if to hide it, but it was evident he was excited to talk about this subject. Not many people to ask questions like that in Signal Hill, you figured. "A miracle granted by The Lady herself. Upon crossing the threshold, their old self's mind was written into the cosmic static and a new self was resurrected in its stead."</p> <p>You raised an eyebrow. "So you worship a zombie?"</p> <p>"I understand that it's unbelievable- all miracles are. But I witnessed it myself." His voice returned to normal, your incredulity taking the wind out of his sails. "If the situation weren't as it is, I'd introduce you to them. But we are all in hiding at the moment."</p> * [[“I assume that has something to do with the theft.”|Cross Theft]]<p>Levi turned up his nose at you, tilting his hat down a little to better cover his face. Maybe trying to hide his annoyance with you. "//Cult leader//. You sound no better than the people who put us here to begin with."</p> <p>"Who knows. Maybe I agree with them." After a beat of hostile silence, you remembered why you were here. "Oh. Yeah, the people who put you here. What do you mean by that?"</p> <p>"There is a... sensitive political situation in the city at the moment. A lot of dominos have been set up, and are waiting to fall. We are unfortunately caught in the middle of all of this."</p> * [[“I assume that has something to do with the theft.”|Cross Theft]]<p>"I would suspect as much." Levi took a moment to gaze around the room, until his eye caught on something. At the bar. A young woman was sitting on a stool the wrong way round, facing towards the two of you. Dressed in a nondescript tee shirt and bootcut jeans. By the time you glanced at her, she was looking past you, out the window. How long had she been sitting there, watching you talk?</p> <p>Levi met your gaze. "Know who that is?"</p> * [[“No idea.”|Cross Walk Out]] * <<link "Try to figure it out. <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-five'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-five'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-tower-broadcast'></i>">><<signalroll 10 "Cross Signal Success" "Cross Signal Failure">><</link>><p>You look back over. A scar stretched from her chin up to her cheek, healed but still recent. Another curled around her arm, from the furthest side of her wrist up to the middle of her bicep. If you lifted her shirt, you'd find more. Dark circles ringed her eyes.</p> <p>She was standing watch, gun by her side, just outside the Quarter. The squad was behind her, warming their hands against an impromptu campfire. It was a quarter to ten. Her captain was smoking a cigarette, the smell of nicotine sharp in the cold night air. She took a few steps forward, curling up her nose. And then the odour abruptly left. The crackling of the fire, the chatter of her squadmates. Silence bore down on her, all encompassing, from every direction.</p> <p>It wasn't just the sounds of the desert and life that left, in that moment. It was a sound she wasn't even aware of. The buzzing of the apocalypse in her ears, for a moment, snuffed out. She started bouncing back and forth on her feet, and the sound of the ash moving under her wasn't there. She took a step forward, and there was no crunching of the rocks.</p> <p>"Workplace hazard." She woke up at 2am. The scars burn like a live wire when you touch them. She can't sleep in a bed with her husband anymore. If he rolled over in his sleep, she could have a seizure. Just as well. She's been known to turn the TV on, leave the VCR off, and watch the static that colonizes its cables. She's been reassigned to patrols- quite the roundabout way to get a cushy job.</p> <p>"Militia," you whispered under your breath across the table. "I don't know if she's here for us, but she's militia."</p> <p>Levi nodded. "It's about time we get going, hm?" He grabbed his beer bottle and started to stand up.</p> * [[You follow.|Cross Walk Out]] <<SetFlag "KnowHarkness">>\<p>You look back over. A scar stretched from her chin up to her cheek, healed but still recent. Another curled around her arm, from the furthest side of her wrist up to the middle of her bicep. Dark circles ringed her eyes.</p> <p>Trying to get a read on her, all you could feel was this overwhelming silence. When your eyes brushed over her scars, it was like the ever-present hum of the apocalypse disappeared for a moment. The absence became a sound in itself, boring into your mind. Once you tore your eyes away, the comforting static returned.</p> <p>"I don't know. But we should leave."</p> <p>Levi nodded. Wordless, he grabbed his beer bottle and started to stand up.</p> * [[You follow.|Cross Walk Out]]<p>Your feet met the ashy cobbled streets of The Stacks. It was as dead during the day as the bar itself, vast networks of empty streets supplying workers to their factories and power plants. In the distance, a bird crowed. You were free to talk now. The two of you started to wander down the open road.</p> <<if Flag("HonestLevi")>>\ <p>"So the cargo. Do you know who stole it?"</p> <p>"Based on what you told me, I'm assuming the worst," Levi muttered. He was still trying to stay quiet. "The Signal Hill militia is... well, they're a powerful organization. They tend to be hands-off in within the city much of the time, hence why you might not have noticed any patrols. The other reason being that they often use plainclothes soldiers to do their dirty work, like our friend back there."</p> <p>In general, getting involved with any organization that called itself a 'militia' was a recipe for disaster. "Why are they so powerful? Is it just firepower?"</p> <p>"If you're interested in a history lesson, I'm afraid you'll have to look elsewhere. The point is that you don't want to mess with them. Or if you do, you'll want to be... intelligent about it. Now, let's get out of sight." He grabbed your wrist and started pulling you through a chain link gate, down an alleyway, between two large brick apartment buildings. Surrounded by trash bags and flies in the ever-present heat of the mid-day sun. You were away from prying ears, at least.</p> * [[“You've got a plan?”|Cross Plan]] <<else>>\ <p>"So the cargo. You don't know who stole it?"</p> <p>"Unfortunately not," Levi shook his head. He was still trying to stay quiet. "We've been targeted before this. One of our church leaders was killed. And I suspect that the person responsible was responsible for this as well, otherwise I'm not sure how they would have identified the cargo and known to steal it. But if I knew who that was, we would have taken care of this long before your companions got shot."</p> <p>//Taken care of it//. You knew what he meant, and he spoke of it like it was effortless. Taking care of it would not be an issue. "But you've got suspects, right?"</p> <p>"Three." He grabbed your wrist and started pulling you through a chain link gate, down an alleyway, between two large brick apartment buildings. Surrounded by trash bags and flies in the ever-present heat of the mid-day sun. You were away from prying ears, at least.</p> * [[“Who are they?”|Cross Suspects]] <</if>>\<p>"A plan of sorts." Levi reached into the pocket of his blue jeans and retrieved a little plastic baggy of neatly folded papers. "I've got some documents in here which match the cargo in question, but the delivery location and recipient has been changed. You'll be complaining to the staff at the depot of an improper seizure at the border. If my hunch is correct, the box will be lacking documentation, and they might just turn it over. At the very least you'll get a look at where it is."</p> <p>You snatched the bag from him and started leafing through the papers- all looked just as official as the stuff the company itself used, not typed with a typewriter but composed with some kind of 'computer program.'<<if $identity.includes("nomad")>> As an experienced caravaneer, you could certainly tell where mistakes had been made- the wrong serif font was used, and the seal at the bottom was that of a different company. Unlikely that anybody else would notice.<</if>> "This is great, but... would that work? If they stole it, they're not just going to let me have it."</p> <p>The man grinned. "That's the thing with bureaucracy, and why I keep a tight grip on my community. The bigger the organization, the more people with oversight over their own little pieces, the easier it is for things to slip between the cracks." He curled one hand into a fist as he spoke, almost unconsciously. "Did they tell the workers in the depot that particular package was illegally stolen and not to be touched? Seems unlikely to me."</p> * [[“That sounds like a solid plan.”|Cross Good Plan]] * [[“And what if they did tell them?”|Cross Backup Plan]]<p>Levi threw his hands up beside his head, open palm, and put on an expression of mock concern. His voice was contorted to sound like he was doing some kind of impression of you, but his impression skills were not great. "Just play dumb and you'll be fine. Getting the cargo would be marvellous, but as long as you get out of there intact with enough information for me to get it myself, I'm satisfied."</p> <p><<if $identity.includes("merc")>>"You don't have to worry about me getting out of there intact." You're on thin ice."</p> <<include "Cross Levi Walks Away">> <<SetFlag "LeviThinIce">>\ <<set $flirt.levi += 1>>\<p>"There's the militia. We've gotten on their bad side a few times, and I know they have an official investigation into us ongoing. Led by a real piece of work I've had to deal with several times, a man by the name of Fitzgerald. They don't have any official justification to act, because of course we are a peaceful religious community. But I know that the people in charge of the investigation would not be against an extrajudicial killing or two."</p> <p>That seemed dubious. "If you're a peaceful religious community, why is there an 'ongoing' investigation?"</p> <p>"Drugs." It was such a matter of fact statement. Yeah, okay. Drugs. They were a cult and drug ring, fair enough. "Which ties into my second suspect. We deal in psychedelics as part of our rituals, and have a close, //exclusive// trade relationship with a local supplier. There's an illegal drug operation in the city, importers and distributors. They've been trying and failing to run us out of the market for years now. I wouldn't put it past them to resort to violence."</p> <p>"Who's in charge of this 'operation,' then?"</p> <p>Levi pursed his lips. "He goes by Yvette. Owns about half the Red Light District."</p> <<if Flag("WorkingForYvette") or $leads.includes("waveform")>>\ <p>Your heart sank a little. Shit, were you working both sides of this conflict? If Yvette turned out to be responsible, you were going to be in huge trouble. Best to play dumb. "A guy named Yvette? Interesting."</p> <p>"Very." Levi was studying you. Your reaction seemed off to him. But he continued. "Be careful around that one, if you ever meet him. He's a snake, complete with fangs."</p> <<else>>\ <p>Your heart sank a little. "Ah, shit. Very bad news."</p> <</if>>\ <p>"And your other suspects?" You were eager to change the subject as quickly as possible.</p> <p>"Well, the owner of the electric company, XElectrics, was assassinated recently." Leaning back against the brick wall behind him with his arms crossed, the guy didn't seem to care much about this assassination he was describing. "Many people in the city have jumped to the conclusion that we were responsible. Somebody high ranking in the company, or even the new owner, could have targeted us for that reason." That seemed... suspicious. But okay.</p> <p>Something didn't quite add up. "Those last two theories... would the electric company or that drug ring even have the means to send a whole squad of heavily armed people to attack us? They were all decked out in body armour, and they all had assault rifles. It wasn't a small time attack at all."</p> <p>"The electric company doesn't technically run the militia, but they might as well. And there are mercenary organizations in this city with more than enough firepower to accomplish that."</p> <ul>\ <<if Flag("ThinksItsDrugs")>>\ <li> [[“This only confirms my theory about drugs. As soon as you laid out the pieces he'd slow clap and nod, congratulating you for having put everything together and cracked the case wide open. "I mean, the box had drugs in it, right? Obviously you were smuggling drugs from the North to Signal Hill to use in rituals or whatever. And this drug ring caught wind of that, and they hired some mercenaries to kill us all so they could steal the drugs and pocket the money. It all makes sense!"</p> <p>You stood there for a painfully long moment, analyzing his cool expression, waiting for confirmation. It never came. "That's a cute theory you've got there. Just keep your mind open when you're investigating, okay?"</p> <p>Cute? //Cute?// This man was a criminal //and// a bastard.</p> * [[“What kind of 'investigation' do you expect me to do, anyway?”|Cross Your Investigation]]<p>"Interesting." His stare gained a distinctly analytical cast, reading every twitch of your eye and tilt of your head. "So why don't you think mercenaries could have been responsible? There is at least one mercenary organization in the area that could've executed that sort of operation."</p> <<if Flag("LamplighterMember")>>\ <p>You couldn't contain a slight, snorting laughter from escaping your lungs. You //knew// KC, and you //knew// her organization. "Slaughter a bunch of caravan guards? That's not their style."</p> <p>"So you know the Lamplighters?" He was squeezing you for information, like a lemon wedge in a vice. Levi was going to get every last drop he could from you. Was it better to be honest, or to deflect? A man like this was going to find out your lies sooner than later.</p> * [[“I am a Lamplighter.”|Cross Lamplighter]] * <<link "“I've encountered them. "Why are you lying to me, <<print $player.name>>?"</p> <p>"Why would I lie about that?" Voice calm, controlled. Don't give anything away. "What, you think I haven't met them? It was just the other day."</p> <p>His upper lip curled. "Must have heard you wrong. My apologies." You won this time.</p> * [[“So what kind of investigation do you expect me to do, anyway?”|Cross Your Investigation]]<p>Levi leaned back against the brick wall, staring you down. It was impossible to maintain eye contact with the sun's rays beating down on you. As soon as you were no longer able to meet his gaze, he spoke, a sound of sickly faux-concern in his voice. "Why are you lying to me, <<print $player.name>>?"</p> <p>"I don't know what you mean." You couldn't keep a nervous laughter from bubbling up. His body was imposing for sure, with those sinewy arms that could crush your throat so easily if you gave him the motivation. But it wasn't that. It was how //collected// he was. You hadn't heard a single quiver in his voice, a single word out of place, this whole time you'd been with him. "I've only done one or two jobs for them, obviously I wasn't working for them when this happened..."</p> <p>"So you are lying to me."</p> <p>Christ. This guy was playing chess, and you were playing checkers.</p> <p>"Can we please just get back to business?" Your legs were shaking a little bit. His exterior was cold as ice, and you couldn't help but shiver with every glance he cast in your direction.</p> <p>Levi nodded. "Let's. Just don't lie to me anymore. I //will// find out."</p> * [[“So what kind of investigation do you expect me to do, anyway?”|Cross Your Investigation]] <<SetFlag "LiedToLevi">>\<p>Levi nodded, his lips pursed in contemplation. If they spend however much on hiring mercenaries to attack you and it leads to your place in the market slipping, they'll make their cash back quickly anyway." You paused. "If I knew what was in that box, I could probably give you a better guess."</p> <p>"I think that's a good enough guess for our purposes." Whatever it was that you'd hauled hundreds of miles across the wastes, Levi was being evasive about it. Even if it would hinder the search. It was //that// secretive.</p> * [[“Speaking of our purposes... what kind of investigation are we doing, anyway?”|Cross Your Investigation]]<p>"Do you know who owns XElectrics?" "Yeah, I met her at a club the other day. She's beautiful."</p> <p>He was still dumbstruck. "I think I'll have to keep you around after we're done investigating..."</p> * [[“Speaking of which... what kind of investigation are we doing, anyway?”|Cross Your Investigation]] <<else>>\ <p>"Not really." One potential angle would be to return to that site and see what was left behind- it could be a long shot, but anything helps. The other option, of course, would be to ask around. People in Signal Hill know more than you expect, and they can be persuaded to share."</p> <<if $skill.glam gte 1 and not $skill.savvy gte 1>>\ So either get a few folks to spill the beans, or trek out to the wasteland to poke around in some bloody ash like CSI? The answer was pretty obvious.</p> * [[“People are unreliable. I'll check out the crime scene first, and ask around later. If we haven't solved it by then.”|Cross Heading Out][$temp = "CSI"]] <<else>>\ <p>Both seemed like valid places to start your little investigation. Either gather the evidence before it's destroyed by the elements, or get information before people forget it- or get tight lipped.</p> * [[“Before I go around playing forensics, I'll see what I can find out the good old fashioned way.”|Cross Heading Out][$temp = "whispering"]] * [[“People are unreliable. I'll check out the crime scene first, and ask around later. If we haven't solved it by then.”|Cross Heading Out][$temp = "CSI"]] <</if>>\<p>Levi gave you a distant shrug, still distracted by the entrance to the alleyway. His body was here, but by now his mind was elsewhere. <<if $glam gte 2>>You could almost pick up on... a sort of grief behind his eyes. <</if>>"I don't care how it gets done," he said, "as long as it gets done. When you've got answers for me, you know where to find me."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“I'll see you soon?” (Hopeful)|Cross Leaving][$temp = "hopeful"]]</li> <li> [[“I'll see you soon.” (Resigned)|Cross Leaving][$temp = "resigned"]]</li> <<if Flag("KidnappedByLevi")>>\ <li> <<link "“And if I fail, are you gonna tie me up again?” (Flirty) <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-four'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-four'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-heart'></i>">><<if $identity.includes("genderfuck")>><<set $bonus += 1>><</if>><<glamroll 8 "Cross Leaving Flirt Success" "Cross Leaving Flirt Failure">><</link>></li> <</if>>\ </ul>\ <<if $temp == "CSI">>\ <<addlead "csisignalhill" "CSI Signal Hill">>\ <<else>>\ <<addlead "whisperingstreets" "Whispering Streets">>\ <<set $whisperingstreetsinfo = 0>>\ <</if>>\<p>With that, Levi tipped the brim of his hat down and pulled his collar up. An attempt to blend in for the short walk home. A man like this, though, could never truly blend in on the streets of Signal Hill. It wasn't just the darkness snaking down his fingers and up around his jaw, but the way he moved. The way his hands gripped the fabric, the sinewy muscle that moved under their ink-stained surface. Like the hands of the ministers that gripped the altar during a forceful sermon in the church of your youth. The arcane scars splayed across his cheek, perhaps self inflicted, or perhaps carved by the ministers who sculpted him into the man standing in front of you. A man like this belonged in a different place, perhaps a different time.</p> <p>He slipped out of the alley, leaving you standing there alone. Next to a pile of garbage bags and an old rusted supply door for some shop. The street was quiet, except for the ever-present buzz in your ear. You stopped to listen for a moment.</p> * [[And then you left too.|Cross Finish]]<h1>"""----""" STORY COMPLETE """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CONTINUE|The Stacks]]</h5> <<unset $temp>>\<h1>"""----""" NEW STORY """----"""</h1> <h5>[[TRACKING NUMBER|Track Building]]</h5><p>After a few minutes of wandering along the paths marked out on Doc's map, you found yourself standing in the center of a flagstone street staring up at the marked building. You looked down at the map for a moment, and then back up. This was it for sure, down to the grocer's located on its left and the tailor's to the right. This nondescript little building was the place you were looking for.</p> <p>Three whole storeys of beige brick, with a few barred windows peeking out into the street. The front entrance was up on a tall foundation with a window at ground level, implying that the bottom floor of this place descended beneath street level, a bit of an odd feature but not unheard of in The Stacks. You had almost wondered if Doc's memory had failed him, but sure enough, here it was. No signage. Nothing indicating a commercial endeavor. Your cargo had been destined for this run-of-the-mill apartment building.</p> <p>Only one thing left to do.</p> * [[Knock on the front door.|Track Knock]]<p>Taking a few steps up the stairs, you could only imagine the ordeal it would have been to get that box inside. It would have fit through the door for sure, but the steps were a little too tall and there wasn't much of a landing at the top.</p> <p>The door was a wooden thing reinforced with metal plates all bolted in place, with a barred window to allow the occupants to see outside. The lock looked heavy duty too. Not uncommon in a place like Signal Hill where your neighbors would sooner steal your shit than wave from across the street, but still a little overkill. Whoever owned this building could afford to install a deterrent like this.</p> <p>Knowing it was some sort of apartment building, you weren't sure whether knocking would even accomplish anything. But you had no other choice. Choosing an area without any sheets of metal, you rapped a few times on the door and waited patiently.</p> * [[And waited.|Track Wait]]<p>You knew your knock had accomplished something. There was a distinct sound from inside, boots on floors, or maybe knocking on an interior door. Somebody had reacted to your knock in some way. But they weren't coming to the door. You stood there for a few minutes, hearing yet more movement inside, unsure what was going on.</p> <p>By the time the idea to knock again had entered your head, you were beaten to the punch by the door swinging open. The hallway inside was dark, with floating dust illuminated by the light streaming in from outside. There in the doorframe, towering over you, was a young man. He was clad in an oversized grey windbreaker and ripped jeans. Half his dark hair was buzzed close to the skin, the other half worn long, wavy, a little tangled. Just under his chin he had the most peculiar tattoo, solid black that went all the way around his neck and faded as it met his chest. He stared down at you with cold blue eyes, and as you stared back, you noticed something odd. Starting directly under his right eye and ringing it like a halo were five long, straight scars. The skin there was lighter than the rest of his olive complexion, and raised, catching the light. <<if $identity.includes("devotee")>>Scars were a mark of religious piety in the North, though you had never seen this particular pattern.<<else>>It was the strangest thing. Certainly didn't happen by accident.<</if>></p> <p>"Can I help you with something?" the man asked in a very slight French accent, leaning against the doorframe with one of his arms on his hip. He was a living contradiction- the casualness of his dress and words couldn't possibly coexist with the severity of his gaze and his smooth, forceful voice. The guy looked like an eagle staring down prey.</p> * [[“It's kind of a long story.”|Track Story]] * [[“Are you expecting a delivery?”|Track Delivery]] * [[“You fucking owe me.”|Track Owe]]<p>The guy folded his arms in front of him and raised an eyebrow at that. "Okay. I've got all day." This wasn't true. His impatience was palpable as you tried to find the words to explain this situation.</p> <p>After fumbling for a moment, you finally gave up. "Maybe... it's best if we talk about this inside."</p> <p>"Look, I've got important business to attend to," he said, turning to go back inside. Ah, shit. This wasn't turning out well. Not well at all.</p> <p>"It's about the delivery," you blurted out just as he had started to shut the door. His head snapped back to stare at you, eyes wide. "It was stolen."</p> * [[That seemed to catch his attention.|Track Tea]]<p>His eyes widened as you mentioned this. "You're with the shipping company?"</p> <p>"Uh... yeah. I'm a contractor." Best to be 100% up front here. You were about to break some pretty bad news.</p> <p>"So... where is it? Do you need me to pay up front? It should be under my name..."</p> <p>Time to do it. No more delays. You had to tell him what happened. You braced for the worst and blurted it out. "The cargo was stolen."</p> <p>In that moment, his face went white. His voice trembled a little. "How about... you come inside?"</p> * [[You follow.|Track Blow]]<p>The guy folded his arms in front of him and raised an eyebrow at that. "I'm sorry, I don't think we've met."</p> <p><<for _item range $outfit.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("tops")>>You lifted up your _item to show the wound off.<</if>><</for>> You gestured to your bandaged midsection, and the clean white surgical bandages had just a bit of blood seeping through them. "I was in that fucking caravan, and I got shot by some assholes who really wanted whatever the hell you were shipping." Rage was bubbling up in your windpipe (or maybe stomach acid). Whatever this asshole's cargo was, //somebody// wanted to steal it, and he should have goddamn known that, so it was his fucking fault you were in this mess to begin with. "On the plus side for you, everybody else is rotting in the ash-wastes, so you only owe a quarter of the fee. Scratch that- //half// for this hole in my side."</p> <p>He stared at you for a moment, just a little longer than you'd expect, and maintaining that anger was getting harder by the second. It was quickly fading. You felt like a cat after being taken out of a bath. There were people just walking by in the street, and they probably thought you were insane.</p> <p>Finally, he broke the silence. "God, that's awful." His voice had a distinct softness to it. "Come in, have a seat in the living room, I'll see about getting that payment for you."</p> * [[Phew. You were worried your anger had scared the guy off.|Track Blow]] * [[You're still indignant. But you enter. Indignantly.|Track Blow]] <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(-10)>>\<p>You ascended that last few steps and followed him into the dusty building. There was a set of wooden stairs leading up to the second floor that was only accessible from the far end of the hallway, and several doors along the way that he bypassed without a second thought. It was dark, and you could just barely see over his shoulder what lay at the end of the hall- a pitch black doorway hanging open like the maw of a beast. Perhaps he was leading you to the stairs. Yeah. That was probably it. "My apologies about the condition of this place," he said, "it was abandoned for some time before the current landlord purchased it. It's a bit of a fixer upper, y'know."</p> <p>Sure enough, when he reached the doorway, he stepped off to the right and gestured at the rickety staircase. "After you."</p> <p>You only took a few steps towards the staircase before you heard a shuffling from behind you, and then the cracking of a large object colliding with your skull.</p> * [[Consider yourself lucky to be unconscious for the part where you fall down an entire set of stairs into the basement.|Track Basement]] <<set $temp = "knocked out">>\<p>"I was just making some tea. Would you like some?" The man had an electric kettle in his hand, the cord spooled up in the other.</p> <p>You found yourself sitting in an armchair in a sort of living room. This place would have looked completely foreign to the residents of Signal Hill. An assortment of things hung from hooks drilled into the ceiling, everything from plant pots overflowing with vines to beadwork wards to knotted ropes crisscrossing the room in various patterns. The wooden floor panels could barely be seen beneath an assortment of rugs, and the walls were lined with photos of holy figures interlaced with hand-painted sigils.</p> <p>What was foreign to a resident of Signal Hill, though, reminded you of sitting in your grandmother's kitchen, the taste of homemade sugar pie, the sound of radio dramas she'd recorded on cassette playing for the hundredth time. This was the home of a Northerner. One who'd seen the old world, or at least someone who knew the style well enough to mimic it.</p> <p>Although the man who seemingly lived here was far too young to be your grandmother, he might as well be ancient for the kind of decor he kept around. He had real old fashioned tea cups, which he sat down on the coffee table on top of a thin lace doily. His face was oddly cool, this unchanging pleasant expression that wasn't quite right.</p> * [[“I'd love some tea.”|Track Tea Yes]] * [[“I'm more of a coffee person.”|Track Tea No]]<p>Sunk into this scratchy jaquard armchair, you watched as he methodically dipped a tea bag into the cup a few times, its string looped over his finger and twirling a small spoon with his other hand. Sliding the cup over to your side of the table, he lingered there, his eyes boring into you.</p> <p>The pressure of his gaze was intense and refused to let up for just a little bit too long. It was impolite not to accept what was offered to you. Hospitality and all. Reluctant, you looped a couple fingers into the handle of the teacup and brought it to your lips.</p> <p>Without any sugar or milk to offset it, a distinctly tart taste permeated your mouth. It had hints of ginger, a vague note of peppermint, and a really strong thing you couldn't identify. Something floral, maybe. Not altogether bad, but the way it stuck in the back of your throat made you wince a little.<<if $identity.includes("devotee")>> There was something familiar about that flavour, something you couldn't quite place.<</if>></p> <p>"So. About this theft." He leaned back in his chair, crossing his legs and pursing his lips. "I'm very interested to hear... how this happened."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[You start to tell him about the ambush.|Track Pass Out]]</li> <<if $identity.includes("devotee") and $player.gender == "androgyne">>\ <li> [[You know you remember that damn taste... what is it?|Track Augur Confirm]]</li> <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>Just like that, it came back to you. Kneeling between two other initiates, the smell of incense, your stomach eating itself out of hunger. Beads and chains and coins hung from your headdress, around your nude form, wrapped around your neck and your arms in elaborate arrangements. The augur stood before you with a ritual dagger and a bottle of a sour-smelling red liquid. You parted your lips as it spilled over your face, feeling it run down your chin and cling to your chest like water from a showerhead. The taste was strange, like fermented flowers. Moments later, your head was spinning, your eyes unfocused, your body tingling.</p> <<if $identity.includes("augur")>>\ * [[Oh no. That's not good.|Track Pass Out]] <<else>>\ <<include "augur">> <p>Would you like to accept this identity?</p> <h1>"""---""" <<link "YES">><<addidentity "augur" "Augur">><<goto "Track Pass Out">><<set $temp1 = "completed">><</link>> / [[NO|Track Pass Out]] """---"""</h1>\ <</if>>\<<if $temp1 == "completed">>\ <p>That was it. You weren't sure what exactly was in that tincture from your initiation, but whatever it was, it was this. That shit knocked you out in only a couple minutes. This wasn't nearly as strong, at least based on the lack of an overpowering fermented taste. But it was the same thing. Shit.</p> <<else>>\ <p>That was it. Not completing the initiation meant you never really discovered what that tincture was, but whatever it was, it was this. That shit knocked you out in only a couple minutes. This wasn't nearly as strong, at least based on the lack of an overpowering fermented taste. But it was the same thing. Shit.</p> <</if>>\ <p>You opened your mouth to try to speak, but nothing came out. Your head was... foggy. There was something you were trying to do. What was it? At the very least, the hole in your side wasn't hurting. And the tingles on your back felt so good. With a shaky hand you took another sip of that tea, hearing the clink of the spoon bouncing against china as if it were underwater.</p> * [[You passed out before you got the chance to put the cup back down.|Track Basement]] <<unset $temp1>>\ <<set $temp = "poisoned">>\<p>"Suit yourself." He plucked a tea bag from a selection set out on the table and you watched as he methodically dipped it into the cup a few times, its string looped over his finger and twirling a small spoon with his other hand. "I'm very curious to hear about this... theft." He sat back into his own, much nicer chair, crossing one leg over the other.</p> <p>"Robbery," you corrected. "It was stolen by armed robbers just outside the city."</p> <p>"Now isn't that unfortunate." He brought the teacup to his lips. You could see his left eye twitch a little. "Oh, I haven't introduced myself... god, where are my manners? I'm Levi." Taking another sip and setting down his cup, he continued. "So, armed robbers, huh? What exactly did theses armed robbers do?"</p> * [[“They fucking shot me, man. And killed everybody else.”|Track Heated]] * [[“They didn't give us a chance to surrender. They killed my companions and tried to kill me.”|Track Calm]] <<set $met.push("levi")>>\<p>"I'm sure you could explain that to me without raising your voice," he muttered. His face looked almost offended. You weren't sure if that was genuine or not. "I'm very sorry about your injury, but it's no reason to be rude."</p> <p>"What the fuck does that mean?" You were ready to lose your temper at this guy. He stood up from his seat to start idly pacing the room, and you continued your little tirade with your eyes fixed to him. "Whatever that package was, somebody tried to kill me for it. I watched a guy get his brains blown out in front of me! Days ago!"</p> <<include "Track Strangle">> <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(-10)>>\<p>"We were maybe a few miles out North of the city, and a whole group of guys with body armour and automatic rifles came at us from the side. They opened fire as soon as they got into range." You recounted the events of that day as efficiently as possible. He could know who almost killed you. It was worth communicating who they were in as much detail as possible, as little as you had.</p> <p>"Jesus," Levi said, his expression somber. "That sounds awful. Were you hurt?"</p> * [[“I sure did better than the other guys.”|Track Quip]] * [[“Yeah.” You show him your bandaged wound.|Track Wound]]<p>Levi stepped behind you, and before you could turn to look at him, a flurry of motion overtook you. There was //something// around your throat, two strong hands on either side of your neck cinching your windpipe, holding you back against the chair. Your hands went to your neck as you struggled to breathe, your legs kicking and trying to buck the chair out of place to no avail. This guy was holding you in place with just his two hands and a braided cord around your throat and there was nothing you could do about it.</p> * [[And then everything went black.|Track Basement]] <<set $temp = "strangled">><p>"I suppose so." He stood up from his seat with an anxious sort of energy in his step, as if to start idly pacing. "It's awful convenient that the rest of your group was killed, and you were barely injured, hm? One might start to suspect some kind of impropriety there."</p> <p>Jesus. Who was this guy, acting like you were some kind of criminal? You were here //to find his package for him//, the asshole! "I'm not sure what you're trying to imply with that, but it's not the case."</p> <<include "Track Strangle">><p>Levi craned his neck to look at your torso as you exposed your bandaged wound. His eyes were calculating, like he was assessing you closely- trying to figure out if there was really an injury under there, perhaps? It was patently obvious, though. You probably needed to get them changed soon, there was blood soaking through right at the edges where there was less padding and some of the surgical tape was coming loose. Anybody could tell that you'd been shot, and that it was bad.</p> <p>"That looks... unfortunate. They must have been very intent on getting that package." His eyes were cold and empty. Behind them, his mind was working, trying to calculate who was behind this. You'd love to help him, but you had no clue either. "Was there anything else you saw? Any more details?"</p> <ul>\ <<if Flag("SeenWolfe")>>\ <li> [[“I do remember... something else.”|Track Details]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if Flag("HeardGeneral")>>\ <li> [[“They mentioned a general.”|Track Military]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[“I don't remember anything else.”|Track Nothing]]</li> </ul>\<p>It was a faint memory. Right before you were shot, before the life started draining out of you. "The guy who shot me. I saw his face. He was... kind of on the short side, freckles, military haircut. His voice was cold... commanding. I think he was in charge of them. When he told them what to do, they did it."</p> <p>Levi leaned in closer, his stare intense. "What did he tell them to do?"</p> <p>"Uh... leave the lid on. They said they were going to crack the lid, and he said it would... um... stress the cargo." There was something else... something. "He... I think he told them to bring it to 'the depot.'"</p> <p>With that, climax, the tension left the room. Levi leaned back in his chair, sinking into its mass. "Ah. There we go. That's what I needed to hear."</p> * [[Wonderful. You did your job. Now... payment?|Track Payment][$temp2 = true]] * [[Okay, now you expect your damn money.|Track Payment][$temp2 = false]] <<SetFlag "HonestLevi">>\ <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(5)>>\<p>It was a faint memory. Right after you were shot, while the life was draining out of you. "I didn't get a good look at the guy who shot me, but he kept giving everybody else instructions. Their commander, I guess."</p> <p>"And you said he mentioned a general?" Levi was leaning in close, his stare intense.</p> <p>"I think... he said something about not getting in trouble with 'the general.' Sounded like they must have been military or something."</p> <p>With that, climax, the tension left the room. Levi leaned back in his chair, sinking into its mass. "Ah. There we go. That's what I needed to hear."</p> * [[Wonderful. You did your job. Now... payment?|Track Payment][$temp2 = true]] * [[Okay, now you expect your damn money.|Track Payment][$temp2 = false]] <<SetFlag "HonestLevi">>\ <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(5)>>\<p>Levi pursed his lips. "That is... unfortunate. Still, very good information." </p> <p>He'd better be satisfied with it, because it was all you could offer. You had gotten shot for that information, and three guys had died for it.</p> * [[You did your job. Now... payment?|Track Payment][$temp3 = true]] * [[Okay, now you expect your damn money.|Track Payment][$temp3 = false]]<<if $temp3 == false>>\ <p>"Okay." You stood up from your chair, brushing a little dust off your legs. This place was a bit of a mess. "You've got what you need. I've done my job. Let's get to the payment."</p> <<elseif $temp3 == true>>\ <p>"That's good to hear. I'm glad I was able to help." You stood up from your chair, brushing a little dust off your legs. This place was a bit of a mess. "Hopefully you'll be able to track it down. However, I'm wondering about my payment."</p> <</if>>\ <<if Flag("HonestLevi")>>\ <p>Nodding, Levi muttered, "You have been both a bearer of bad news and a great help. And you have technically brought the cargo... to the city, at least. I think that's worth payment."</p> <<if $temp3 == false>>\ <p>"No kidding." Gesturing again to your nearly fatal wound, you argued, "I almost died on this job. If anything, I should be getting more."</p> <<elseif $temp3 == true>>\ <p>"I would certainly hope so." Gesturing again to your nearly fatal wound, you muttered, "It would help pay for... this."</p> <</if>>\ <p>"Let me make you a proposal." He took a long sip of his tea, his face uncomfortably neutral. "You've earned your original payment. But I still don't have the cargo. Now, the process of getting this back... let's just say, I can't go through //official channels// for an assortment of very good reasons. Help me retrieve it, and I'll double the original paycheck."</p> <<set $temp3 == true>>\ <<else>>\ <p>Levi took a long sip of his tea, a dark look in his eyes. "I don't have my cargo. And I don't know where it is. If I recall correctly, that means the contract is void. I don't owe you anything."</p> <p>You were almost speechless. All of this, for nothing? "I can't just leave without getting paid. I got shot almost to death trying to deliver this! Is that not worth anything to you?!"</p> <p>In an instant, he slammed his teacup back down on the saucer, the sound of ceramic against ceramic reverberating through the room. You felt all your muscles tense up. The saucer was cracked down the middle, and the tag on the teabag swung from the rim of the teacup as it settled in place. "You didn't let me finish." His voice was set in that same uncomfortable cool, not a trace of the anger present in his actions. "I will pay you if you deliver the cargo as negotiated."</p> <p>"I'm sorry?"</p> <p>"Assist me in tracking it down, and you will get your payment."</p> <p>It was insanity. "Double. Double the payment, and I'll consider it."</p> <p>"My... that's a big ask. But I think my pocketbook can handle it." He leaned over in his chair, placing his weight on one elbow on the arm, one hand laying neatly on he other. From violent outburst to casual in an instant.</p> <</if>>\ <p>You were at a veritable standstill. Looking into his eyes, you knew that he knew that he was in total control here. <<if $temp3 == true>>He could offer you four times your payment, and he'd still only be spending what he had budgeted for the delivery. And you didn't exactly have any bargaining chips anymore to force him to pay up. <<else>>He was holding the payment over your head, and if you wanted anything, you'd just have to go along with it. And the real kicker? Whatever he offered you, he was still going to be saving money now that he only had one person to pay. <</if>>The bastard was smart, you could say that much.</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Hell yeah. Let's do it.”|Track Agree]]</li> <li> [[“That sounds fair.”|Track Agree]]</li> <li> <<link "“That's a big ask. You're going to need to sweeten the deal a little.” <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-brain'></i>">><<savvyroll 8 "Track Savvy Success" "Track Savvy Failure">><</link>></li> <<if $temp3 == true>>\ <li> [[“That's bullshit. Do it your damn self.”|Track Take Money]]</li> <li> [[“That's not really my speed. I'll just take what I'm due and move on.”|Track Take Money]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[“That's bullshit. Do it your damn self.”|Track Disagree]]</li> <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>"Very well." Levi seemed satisfied with your performance. "I'll just have to hire somebody else. No big loss."</p> <p>You accepted your payment. Finally. The money you were due. This whole headache was finally over, and you could move on with your meager starter cash and get to the more important stuff. Whatever this cargo was... well, you weren't destined to find out. Not now, at least.</p> <p>Stepping back out into the smoggy, ash-choked city air, you left Levi and his strange home and his mysterious cargo behind.</p> * [[You were ready to set out on the real journey.|Track Finish]] <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(-10)>>\<p>"Very good." He glanced up at the ceiling, although with the decorations you couldn't tell for sure if he was contemplating something or getting distracted.</p> <p>"So what exactly is this job going to entail?"</p> <<if Flag("HonestLevi")>>\ <p>"I'm going to need somebody who is not publicly associated with me to inquire with the local militia about seized cargo." There was math going on behind his eyes- he was still actively formulating this plan as he spoke. "We may need to forge some documents... it can not be clear to them that I was the intended recipient. They would know that you are not me."</p> <p>Why the militia would know who he was on sight wasn't of any concern to you. Maybe you could ask that later. "Yeah, okay. I can lie to some military pencil-pushers. No big deal."</p> <<else>>\ <p>"We still need to determine who was responsible for stealing the cargo." There was math going on behind his eyes- he was still actively formulating this plan as he spoke. "Perhaps I can send you back to the scene of the crime, as it were. Or we can discuss the likely suspects and attempt to narrow down the list."</p> <p>"You don't seem like you have a very clear idea yet."</p> <p>He shook his head. "I don't. This is a major inconvenience. And we have something of a time limit. Just... how about you meet me at the Juice Bar on Main, and we'll discuss it later, once I've gotten my thoughts in order."</p> <p>"Okay. Yeah, sounds good."</p> <</if>>\ * [[With that, it was time to leave this strange place. For now.|Track Finish]] <<set $temp5 = true>>\<p>"Very well." Levi seemed completely unphased by this rejection. "Your loss. I have several dozen people who could do it instead, and the means to hire even more." It was almost... bragging? You couldn't quite ascribe that to him, this man who seemed characterized by aloofness. Whatever he was doing, it felt wrong to call it 'bragging.' This was an accurate assessment of his means.</p> <p>"My money, then?"</p> <p>"You have not done your job. Your contract is void. Leave."</p> <p>You were stunned into silence. Who the fuck was this man, refusing to pay you after all you'd done for him? It wasn't your goddamn fault you had no information for him. It boiled your blood.</p> * [[You storm out, intent on making money elsewhere.|Track Storm]] * [[You decide the best way to proceed is to take your money by force.|Track Force]]<p>Without so much as another word, you flipped the guy off and stormed out of the front door. This was the last shipping job you were ever going to fucking take. Time to get into a safer industry- become a merc or a fishpacker or some shit. Whatever happened, this path was forever blocked off from you.</p> <p>There went your paycheck. But then again... if this cargo was worth so much, you could probably get a pretty penny for it if you tracked it down first. Just maybe.</p> * [[Good riddance.|Track Finish]] <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(-20)>>\<p>No more fucking around. You were going to get your money, one way or another. <<if $heldweapon.has('semi-auto pistol')>>You drew your pistol from its holster and aimed it directly at the guy's head.<<elseif $heldweapon.has('hunting rifle')>>You started getting the strap of your rifle over your head, ready to get a good shot off on this guy.<<elseif $heldweapon.has('.44 magnum revolver')>>You drew your revolver from its holster and aimed it directly at the guy's head.<<elseif $heldweapon.has('sawed-off shotgun')>>You lifted your shotgun out of its holster, brandishing it at the man.<<elseif $heldweapon.has('combat knife')>>You brandished your knife- admittedly not the scariest weapon to threaten someone with, but your current best option.<<elseif $heldweapon.has('spiked bat')>>You brandished your bat at him, a threatening sight indeed.<</if>> But before you could even make a verbal threat, he'd drawn his own weapon- a slick black pistol which had been tucked into his jean pocket. He'd fired in an instant, and you dropped to the ground.</p> <p>As the blood leaked from your body from your second bullet wound in only a few days, Levi stepped around the coffee table to look down on you. You must have been a dour sight, bleeding into the rugs and staining them for sure. The last thing you saw was him shaking his head at you, and the inside of the barrel of his pistol before another shot rang out.</p> * [[Bang. Dead.|Track Dead]]<h1>YOU DIED.</h1> <p style="text-align: center">//Let's try that again, shall we?//</p> <h1>"""------""" [[GO BACK|Track Payment]] """------"""</h1><p>"Look, Levi," you started, formulating your pitch as you went. "I don't know what's in that box, but it's clearly of pretty significant importance to you. So much that you were willing to pay all of that to get it here. Now, you're offering me //half// the total payment?"</p> <p>"You are one quarter of the people hired. Half is generous." Still he was hearing you out.</p> <p>Shaking your head slowly, you said, "I don't think you really believe that. You're a real smart guy, I can tell- and I think you're smart enough to know you're lowballing me here. But I'm not asking for the full payment."</p> <p>Levi's interest was piqued. "You aren't? Okay, go on."</p> <p>"Three quarters. You're still making out with a deal, right? But now we're both profiting. It's a win-win. I get to do this work for you for reasonable pay, and you get to save a buck while getting... basically, free work."</p> <p>There was a long pause, and you couldn't analyze his face at all. It wasn't clear if he was considering your offer or considering who else to hire in your stead. If he refused, well... he had all the bargaining chips.</p> <p>"I know what you're trying to do here, <<print $player.name>>." Levi gazed at you with those dark blue eyes full of thought, and infinitely smarter than you even as you tried your hardest to outwit him. "And I want you to know that I'm agreeing because I find your attempt endearing, not because it worked. Your original payment up front, and the other two quarters once the cargo is acquired."</p> * [[Close enough. Jackpot.|Track Agree]] <<set $temp5 = true>>\ <<set $temp6 = true>>\ <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(5)>>\<p>"Look, Levi," you started, formulating your pitch as you went. "I don't know what's in that box, but it's clearly of pretty significant importance to you. So much that you were willing to pay all of that to get it here. Now, you're offering me //half// the total payment?"</p> <p>"You are one quarter of the people hired. Half is generous." Still he was hearing you out.</p> <p>Shaking your head slowly, you said, "I don't think you really believe that. You're a real smart guy, I can tell- and I think you're smart enough to know you're lowballing me here. This is big work- it's easily four times the caravan job. Four times the payment isn't even enough, but I'll accept it."</p> <p>A smile crept across Levi's face. It was cold, unfeeling. "This is an endearing attempt, <<print $player.name>>. However, I'm not sure if you know how things work around here. I'm the one who sets the prices. And you will agree to them, or you will leave with nothing. Understood?"</p> * [[“Bullshit. This is ridiculous.”|Track Disagree]] * [[“Fine. I'll do it.”|Track Agree]]<p>The first thing you felt, before your eyes even opened, was leather straps digging into your wrists. Then, cold metal against your back. Your teeth were held apart by a thick fabric gag that had been tied around your head, and your feet were restrained, a rope wrapped around them and secured to something strong.</p> <p>Then, another thing came into focus- a throbbing headache, right in your temple. <<if $temp == "knocked out">>That must have been where he hit you.<<elseif $temp == "poisoned">>The painkilling effects of that tea had evidently worn off by now.<<else>>It even eclipsed the pain from the rope burn around your neck.<</if>> That pain was telling you to keep your eyes firmly shut. Beyond them there was light, foul light, so bright it was glowing through your lids. If you opened them, it was going to kill you for sure. You'd go into shock or something. This headache was going to burst a blood vessel if it got any worse. At least, that's what it felt like.</p> * [[Ignore it. Open them.|Track Open]] * [[Obey. Keep them closed.|Track Closed]] <<SetFlag "KidnappedByLevi">>\<p>If it were possible to squeeze your eyes shut any further, you would have done it. You lay there a little longer, listening to the ambience of the room through the pounding in your skull. There was a low buzz, some kind of electric light right above you, the source of your woes. The whirring of a fan. And footsteps against concrete. Listening long enough, they came towards you, and back away, and back towards you again. Your captor was pacing.</p> <p>After a little while, you heard a voice. Not the same voice as before- surely the same person, but not the same voice. It was disjointed and rushed, far from the smooth delivery of his practised persona. "Christ, what's taking so long? This shit shouldn't be that potent..."</p> <p>Oh. He didn't know you were awake yet. Maybe if you kept still, he wouldn't kill you. Good plan.</p> <p>"Stolen... how? Nobody knew. Nobody was //supposed// to know." He had stopped, now. Right next to the table. Standing over you. You kept your eyes squeezed shut, away from the light, away from him. Like a child. Pathetic.</p> <p>The whine of the light was interrupted by <<if $met.includes("levi")>>Levi's<<else>>the man's<</if>> voice again, this time right by your head. "You're awake, aren't you? How long have you been awake? Open your fucking eyes." He sounded more exasperated than murderous.</p> * [[Okay... you open them.|Track Delayed Open]]<p>Mind over matter. Your eyes fluttered open, and in an instant you were blinded. A bright flourescent sat only a few feet above your head, shining right at you, bright white and uncompromising. It bored into your skull.</p> <p>You turned your head to get away from the cruel light, and as your eyes adjusted, the first thing they saw was your captor. He standing in front of a metal counter on the other side of the room, which was pushed up against an exposed brick wall. His windbreaker<<if $temp == "knocked out">>, now spattered with blood,<</if>> had been discarded on a chair in the corner in favour of a black tank top, revealing his bare skin underneath. But it was far from bare- his sinewy arms were covered in black ink, large unbroken fields of it ringing his defined biceps and the forms of delicate vines and mushrooms spreading off from there. Unbroken except for raised skin, yet more short scars arranged in uniform rings and odd patterns across his flesh.</p> * [[Your kidnapper. Who will probably murder you soon.|Track Kidnapped]] * [[Your kidnapper. But you have to admit... he's kinda hot.|Track Hot]]<p>In this light, you saw him much differently. <<if $temp == "knocked out">>Maybe it was the brain damage,<<elseif $temp == "poisoned">>Maybe you were still a little loopy,<<else>>Maybe it was the lack of oxygen to your brain,<</if>> but you kept thinking about how that tank top was a much better choice of clothing for him. It clung tight enough for you to see his shoulder blades and the subtle curve of his waist through the thin ribbed knit. Underneath it, his body was lean but strong, waist narrow like one of those old statues with no heads. And his arms... swoon. Sure, he knocked you out and tied you up in his basement, but we all have our flaws. Maybe if you played your cards right then by the end of the night you'd be gagging on something else. And also not get murdered.</p> <p>Were you really objectifying your kidnapper? Yes. Yes you were. And you should be ashamed.</p> <p>Your dreamy-eyed musings were cut short when <<if $met.includes("levi")>>Levi<<else>>the guy<</if>> glanced over his shoulder and caught you staring. He started towards you with a calm expression on his face.</p> <ul>\ <li> <<link "Try to look, like, cute and helpless or something. <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-six'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-six'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-heart'></i>">><<if $identity.includes("genderfuck")>><<set $bonus += 1>><</if>><<glamroll 12 "Track Glam Success" "Track Glam Failure">><</link>></li> <li> [[Okay, maybe it's time to take this seriously.|Track Confront]]</li> </ul>\ <<if not $attraction.includes("levi")>>\ <<set $attraction.push("levi")>>\ <</if>>\<p>There was something so... normal about him. It was offputting. He'd tied you up in his basement, and yet he was going about his business with his shoulders relaxed and his toe tapping. You were pretty sure you were about to get tortured to death, but just by looking at him, you'd think he was getting dinner ready. Maybe he was. All sorts of freaks out there.</p> <p>You inhaled sharply as you watched him glance over his shoulder at you. He started towards you, his expression calm. Like somebody who'd gut you and eat you for dinner, perhaps.</p> * [[You're unable to move from fear. And also from the restraints.|Track Confront]]<p>Reluctant, you let one eye open just enough to see what was going on around you. You were glad that the light was no longer shining directly into your eyes. You were not glad to see that the thing blocking it was your captor looming over you. He was almost just a silhouette in front of the bright fluorescent, dark shadows cast over the forms of his strong nose and sharp jaw. He'd shed his windbreaker in favour of a black ribbed tank top, which exposed enough skin that you could make out the true extent of his tattoos underneath. His sinewy arms were covered in black ink, large unbroken fields of it ringing his defined biceps and the forms of delicate vines and mushrooms spreading off from there. But there was something else, something you could only see clearly in such bright light- raised areas on his skin, like around his eye. They adorned it like some kind of elaborate star chart, winding in concentric circles of dotted lines and longer lines spreading out from central points.</p> <p>"I've been waiting for you. Wasting my time right now is a pretty bad decision." His voice was dry, unfeeling. But there was a casual edge to it. You might not have clocked it as robotic at the time, but his voice had sure sounded robotic before. "I want to make this easy on you, okay? But you're gonna have to work with me."</p> <p>That was when you noticed what was in his right hand- a sizable metal cleaver. He was idly running the sharp edge along his jeans, and you could tell it was sharp and heavy enough to cut through bone without much issue. "Oh, this?" When he noticed you staring, a grin spread across his face, and he hefted the knife up where you could examine it more easily. "This is just for cutting all those ropes you're tangled up in once you answer all my questions. Cooperate, and it'll stay that way."</p> * [[You're gagged, but you try to respond anyway.|Track Gagged]]<p>You stared up at your captor as he loomed over you. His eyes, deep blue, scanned you with a distinct indifference. Like he wasn't particularly interested. Like this was a job.</p> <p>"Good to see you're up. That was a real nasty fall you took." After a moment without any response from his captive audience, a grin spread across his face- the first you'd seen on him. "I'm just fucking with you. Look, I'm going to try to make this easy on you, but you've gotta do the same for me. We're gonna work together on this, okay?"</p> <p>His speech was much looser, more casual here. He was putting on an image before. This was where he felt comfortable. Concerning, given what he revealed was in his hand- a sizable metal cleaver.</p> <p>"Oh, this thing?" When he caught you glancing at it, he raised it up for easier viewing, twisting it so it gleamed in the fluorescent light. "It's for cutting those ropes you're all tangled up in once you answer my questions, of course. I won't need to use it for anything else so long as you help me out."</p> * [[You're gagged, but you try to respond anyway.|Track Gagged]]<p>Letting out a pitiful whimper through the gag, you tried to form words around the cloth stuck between your teeth. Your jaw was getting sore from the constant pressure and the knot was digging into the back of your neck. Eventually, he rolled his eyes at your struggling and decided to do something about it. He looped a finger under the gag and braced his other hand against your jaw, yanking the fabric up and pulling your neck with it in the process. With the knot tightened and the gag loosened, he was able to slip it over your chin and leave you free to speak.</p> <p>"Now, let's start with the questions, shall we?"</p> * [[“I just wanna get this over with.”|Track Questions][$temp1 = "cooperative"]] * [[“Are you kidding me? Fuck no! I'm not answering shit! Let me go!”|Track Refuse][$temp1 = "uncooperative"]]<p>Struggling against your bounds only led to the ropes getting tighter, constricting your limbs and keeping you trapped against this table. It was no use.</p> <p>"I don't think you've understood me," <<if $met.includes("levi")>>Levi<<else>>your captor<</if>> intoned. He hefted his cleaver above your hand, as if ready to strike. "You're going to answer my questions. Honestly. Okay?"</p> * [[“Okay, okay, fuck. Yeah, I'll answer your damn questions.”|Track Questions]] * [[“I'm not scared of you, bastard! Let me the fuck out!”|Track Bastard]] <<set $relationship.levi to $relationship.levi.fm(-10)>>\<p>"Okay. Have it your way then. But I recommend spreading out those fingers of yours so I don't take out two by accident."</p> <<set $nextpassage = "Track Questions">>\ <<include "Track Chop">>\<p>You stared up at your captor as he loomed over you. His eyes, deep blue, scanned you with a distinct indifference. Like he wasn't particularly interested. That was a problem, of course.</p> <p>"Good to see you're up. You really kept me waiting there."</p> <p>It would be damn near impossible to seduce the guy if you were gagged like this, so you started making noise in hopes that he would free you. Not too much. Pointed noise. Best not to act like you were freaking out, otherwise he might get annoyed.</p> <p>This plan seemed successful, as he hooked a finger around your gag. You could feel his skin against yours. "Go ahead, say whatever it is you want to say. If you start screaming or something, I'm gonna shut you up again." He yanked on the fabric hard and your neck was pulled up with it as the knot tightened. The gag was loose enough now for him to pull it down over your chin.</p> <p>Intent on not wasting this first impression, you chose your words carefully. You tried to say something through the gag, but it was like, really in there and the whole thing came out incoherent.</p> <p>Your captor tilted his head to the side, a puzzled expression creeping onto his face. It's in the contract, we'd lose our pay." That wasn't quite a lie. Everybody did it, if they knew they could get away with it. You knew a few fuckers who'd stolen a ton cash out of a shipment and just took the money and disappeared before it was discovered. Your worst consequence would be getting blacklisted by the shipping company, but there are a million goddamn caravans in this area.</p> * [[This one, though, none of you dared touch it.|Track Max]]<p>You talked about it on the second or third night, huddled around a fire, shooting the shit with a couple bottles and a few cigarettes. One of them put forward the idea- his name was Max, you think. "That shit freaks me out," he'd murmured. "I swear to god there's something weird in there. I don't know what, but it's giving me vibes that are all outta whack."</p> <p>"I think it's probably some kind of electronics," another guy, Junior, volunteered. Through the smoke, you could barely see his face. "When I was loading it into the back, I swear I heard, like... radio sounds. Inside. Like there's a radio draining batteries in there. And some kind of whirring, too."</p> <p>Dexter, the guy who'd helped Junior carry the box, nodded in agreement. "Makes sense, cause that shit was heavy. Weird container for it, though. All that duct tape and caulk and shit. Gonna be a bitch to get open."</p> <p>"What, you wanna open it?"</p> <p>"I mean, I'm curious," Dexter admitted after a puff off his cigarette. "I'd do it if I thought I could get away with it."</p> * [[“Let's crack it open, then.”|Track Crack]] * [[“Are you insane? We can't open it.”|Track Insane]]<p>Dexter and Junior murmured in agreement, nodding along with you. "We oughtta at least take a peek," one of them concurred. "Might be really fucking expensive."</p> <p>"You guys are nuts," Max piped up. His face, illuminated oddly by the firelight, was all twisted up in a concerned expression. "How would you close it back up without it being obvious? That thing is sealed airtight. You're gonna lose all our paychecks for this. And it's a massive paycheck."</p> <p>A silence fell over the group, and all you could hear was the crackling of the fire. Finally, somebody piped up. "Fair point." And that was the end of the discussion. You never found out what was in it, and unless they were really good at caulking and brought a lot of duct tape, none of them did either. If that mattered. The brains that knew would be decomposing into the ash wastes by now, or picked apart by birds.</p> * [[And you might join them if you don't focus on the matter at hand.|Track Second]]<p>You had to be the voice of reason here. "With all that on it, it's gonna be obvious we opened it. If you guys wanna lose your paychecks, that's fine, but don't cost me mine."</p> <p>A silence fell over the group, and all you could hear was the crackling of the fire. Finally, somebody piped up. "Fair point." And that was the end of the discussion. You never found out what was in it, and unless they were really good at caulking and brought a lot of duct tape, none of them did either. If that mattered.
