You were walking right through the main drag, where grocers and butchers had their goods on show out front in the mid-day sun, and little stands hung top-to-bottom with Northern beadwork were attended by their elderly owners. You had to dodge and weave a little to get through the crowd.</p> <p>"Why, exactly? What's the big deal?" KC didn't seem particularly easy to upset. In fact, she seemed quite the opposite.</p> <p>Doc seemed a little put off by the question. "Well, see, it's... a very complicated relationship. She is not a fan of me at the moment. We had some business dealings that fell through." You almost wanted to question him further, but he wasn't having it. "Have you met anybody else?"</p> <ul><li> <<link "“Well, I met this guy who owns a brothel in the Red Light District.”">><<if $leads.includes("waveform")>><<set $temp1 = true>><<elseif $playedleads.includes("waveform")>><<if Flag("WorkingForYvette")>><<set $temp1 = true>><<else>><<set $temp1 = false>><</if>><<else>><<set $temp1 = false>><</if>><<goto "Checkup Red Light">><</link>></li></ul><p>"The Lamplighters, you mean?" He pursed his lips. His heels clicked against the paving stones underfoot, these leather Western boots with patterns stamped into the sides. "Have you been working with them?"</p> <<if Flag("LamplighterEnemy")>>\ <p>"Uh... you could say that." Bit of an awkward situation, huh? "I certainly tried, but y'know. Speaking of which- have you met anybody else?"</p> <ul><li> <<link "“Well, I met this guy who owns a brothel in the Red Light District.”">><<if $leads.includes("waveform")>><<set $temp1 = true>><<elseif $playedleads.includes("waveform")>><<if Flag("WorkingForYvette")>><<set $temp1 = true>><<else>><<set $temp1 = false>><</if>><<else>><<set $temp1 = false>><</if>><<goto "Checkup Red Light">><</link>></li></ul><p>When the words left your mouth, Doc nearly tripped over a paving stone. <<if $temp == true>>Lucky that you took the box from him, or that could have been a disaster.<<else>>He barely recovered in time to keep the box from falling out of his arms, a look of sheer panic crossing his face as loud clinking rang out from within the package.<</if>> After taking a moment to collect himself, he blinked a few times and started off walking again. You quickly found yourself trying to keep up with Doc, rather than walking with him. "<<if $finishedleads.includes("roseandthorn")>>The one person I told you //not// to associate with, and you immediately seek her out.<<else>>How did you manage to immediately track down the one person in the city you //weren't// supposed to associate with?<</if>> My god, <<print $player.name>>."</p> <p>This was probably the most overt emotion you'd ever seen Doc express, and it was completely out of left field. You sped up to a light jog,<<if $temp == true>> accompanied by the sound of glass clinking together in the box in your arms,<</if>> trying to catch up to him.</p> <<if $temp1 == true>>\ * [[“What the hell is wrong with me hanging out at The Rose?”|Checkup Hell True]] * [[“Hey, Doc, slow down... what's wrong?”|Checkup Slow True]] <<else>>\ * [[“What the hell? "It's not about the establishment, or The Red Light District... none of that. It's about Yvette."</p> <p>"What's wrong with Yvette? He's been very hospitable to me so far!" You started climbing up the stairs into The Heights. "I'm an adult. If he tries to pull some shit, I'll leave."</p> <p>It occurred to you in that moment that you hadn't really heard Doc laugh before. But he was laughing now. Just a nervous little chuckle under his breath. "Oh, no you won't. You absolutely won't."</p> <p>"I can make my own decisions."</p> <p>"Yes, you can." Finally, as he walked towards the radio tower that loomed over the city, Doc got his composure back. "I'm not your father. You can work with whoever you choose to work with. Just know that I don't support it. Now, we should stop talking about this."</p> <p>That was probably a good idea. You'd never seen an outburst like this from the usually reserved doctor. He was absolutely livid. What caused him to act like this, you couldn't say.</p> * [[Best to move on now.|Checkup Move On]] <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(-5)>>\<p>Realizing how he was coming off, Doc immediately slowed back down, holding his head high. I don't know what got into me. Frankly, I'm a little upset."</p> <p>God, even when he was upset he spoke like a robot. "What's the big deal? So I'm working with Yvette. He doesn't seem that bad. He's like... an entrepreneur."</p> <p>"You don't understand what a bad idea this is. Whatever she's said, she is not being honest with you." He seemed so certain of this. Just know that I don't support it. Now, we should stop talking about this."</p> <p>That was probably a good idea. You'd never seen an outburst like this from the usually reserved doctor. What caused him to act like this, you couldn't say.</p> * [[Best to move on now.|Checkup Move On]] <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)>>\<p>Realizing how he was coming off, Doc immediately slowed back down, holding his head high. Calm- or calmer. He was trying his best to look composed, but as you came around his side, you could see the flush under his freckles.</p> <p>"My apologies, <<print $player.name>>. I don't know what got into me. Frankly, I'm a little upset." He was staring down at the <<if $temp1 == true>>paving stones<<else>>box in his hands<</if>> intently, as if he could remove himself from this situation with enough focus.</p> <p>"I'm not working with Yvette. <<if $playedleads.includes("waveform")>>It didn't work out.<<else>>He didn't seem like somebody I wanted to associate with.<</if>> I get your concern, but I can handle myself."</p> <p>"Oh, thank the lord." There was a genuine look of relief on his face. "<<print $player.name>>, I hope you know I want what's best for you. I am your physician now. I just want to make sure you aren't getting hurt."</p> <p>Both of you slowed down for a moment, in step. Like you were both surprised by what he just said. "I appreciate that, Doc."</p> <p>"Now. How about we just drop the subject, okay?"</p> <p>That was probably a good idea. You'd never seen an outburst like this from the usually reserved doctor. What caused him to act like this, you couldn't say.</p> * [[Best to move on now.|Checkup Move On]] <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)>>\<<styletest>>\ <p>By this point, you'd nearly reached the circle at the beating heart of The Heights' shopping district. <<if _result == "luxury">>You fit in here, among all the folks in their fashionable shorts and breezy tie-front shirts and printed button ups. Doc, on the other hand... well, he had his own personal sense of style. It wasn't a stylish one, though.<<else>>Neither of you really fit in here, among all the folks in their fashionable shorts and breezy tie-front shirts and printed button ups.<</if>> You weren't out in the open for long, though. As soon as you'd circled around the left side of the radio station, Doc made a hard left and veered into the space between two buildings. You had no choice but to follow behind him and squeeze into this little alley.</p> <p>Once you got around the sleek stucco walls, the space opened up into a larger side street. It appeared to wrap around the backs of all these buildings, where one could access their employee entrances and secret storage areas. A number of large dumpsters lined the back walls, and this building in particular had a large wooden addition built out of its back, far scrappier than anything customer-facing.</p> <p>"This is the nicest apothecary in town," Doc muttered under his breath as he stepped up to the back door. "They pay very well for 'artisinally produced' medicines- so that the owners don't need to do any real chemistry in-house."</p> <<if $temp == true>>\ <ul><li> [[You wait for Doc to knock on the back door.|Checkup Knock]]</li></ul> <<else>>\ <ul><li> [[Doc's hands are a little full, so you knock on the back door for him.|Checkup Knock]]</li></ul> <</if>>\<p><<if $temp == true>>Doc stepped up and gave the back door a polite knock, and then when nothing happened, a much harder one.<<else>>You rapped your fist against the metal door and stepped back as you heard rustling inside.<</if>> Eventually, the door swung open and an older gentleman was peering at you from the comparative darkness inside. It was some kind of storage room, full of large shelves of cardboard boxes, all labelled with thick black marker. Laudanum, cocaine, acetaminophen, morphine. Looked like a fun time.</p> <p>"Ah, took you long enough." The man reached out and snatched the package from <<if $temp == true>>your hands<<else>>Doc's grasp<</if>>, the contents rattling as they were jerked around. "Let me open it up first."</p> <p>Doc nodded. "Go ahead. I can wait."</p> <p>The two of you stood outside as the man dropped this new shipment on a table and started rifling through it. You couldn't see the inside from where you were standing, but you could hear the shifting of powder inside of vials as he shook them. "Perfect. All look pure as usual. You're a gifted chemist, Emil."</p> <p>"I try." So that was his real name!</p> * [[You're going to have to find a way to use this against him! At all costs!|Checkup Payment][$temp2 = true]] * [[Interesting. But he prefers being called Doc, of course.|Checkup Payment]]<p>The store's proprietor grabbed an envelope full of cash and handed it off to Doc, waiting by the door as the doctor opened it up and thumbed through it. "Thank you, sir."</p> <p>"When's the next batch of ascorbic acid going to be ready, exactly?"</p> <p>Doc gazed up at the sky for a moment, his lips pursed. "Let me see... a week at the latest."</p> <p>"Alrighty. Always a pleasure doing business with you, doctor." The man nodded and gave you both a cordial wave before heading back inside and shutting the door behind him.</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Jesus, that's some good money right there.”|Checkup Money]]</li> <li> [[“I didn't know you sold drugs.”|Checkup Drugs]]</li> <<if $temp == true>>\ <li> [[“Did I earn any of that?”|Checkup Earn]]</li> <</if>>\ </ul>\ <<if $temp2 == true>><<addlead "emilzhao" "Dr. Emil Zhao">><</if>>\<p>Doc stuffed the envelope into the deep pocket of his overcoat- probably why he was so overdressed. "Apart from Joyette's sliding scale and the occasional charitable donation, this is the only way the clinic gets funding."</p> <p>"So... you don't keep it?" Bummer.</p> <p>"No. I don't. Some of it goes to paying my salary, but that's a pretty meager portion." <<if $temp == true>>Now that the delivery had been made<<else>>No longer weighed down by his cargo<</if>>, Doc set off with a much lighter step towards the main street. "I don't think you're going to want to hear all about operating a business, though. Let's head back, shall we?"</p> * [[And you set off after him.|Checkup Set Off]]<p>Doc stuffed the envelope into the deep pocket of his overcoat- probably why he was so overdressed. He was amused by your implication, a smile barely tickling his cheeks. "I did say I was a druggist, didn't I? This is all I do."</p> <p>"You do a hell of a lot more than that. <<if Flag("ReattachedFinger")>>You stitched my damn finger back on<<else>>You sewed up a bullet hole for me<</if>>, remember?"</p> <p>"Some might call me a jack of all trades," Doc muttered. <<if $temp == true>>Now that the delivery had been made<<else>>No longer weighed down by his cargo<</if>>, he set off with a much lighter step towards the main street. "I'm just glad I can do something. Now let's head back, shall we?"</p> * [[And you set off after him.|Checkup Set Off]]<p>He was clearly amused by your question, a smile barely tickling his cheeks. "Earned? By carrying the box?"</p> <p>"I carried it pretty far," you reasoned, only half joking. "There were a lot of steps. Really, I think you might owe me."</p> <p>Doc opened up the envelope and fished out a single bill before stuffing it into the deep pocket of his overcoat- probably why he was so overdressed. "Here, your payment. For being a useful workhorse for 10 minutes." He held it out for you- a pittance, not enough to buy even the cheapest drink from the worst bar in town. You snatched it up anyway. "Now, let's head back, shall we?"</p> * [[And you set off after him.|Checkup Set Off]]<p>Back out into the street, down the steps, the two of you set off back towards Skid Row. Around the point where you veered off down the main street in The Stacks, Doc turned to you with raised eyebrows. "Oh my god, I nearly forgot to ask. Your cargo!"</p> <p>"My cargo?"</p> <p>"Your cargo! Did you make any progress in tracking it down?" A hopeful little smile spread across his lips. He'd been waiting for the resolution to this mystery... well, since you had left his office the first time. "What happened when you went to that address?"</p> <<if Flag("WorkingForLevi")>>\ <p>So... this was awkward. You had in fact made progress, yes. But Levi was very clear that you should not tell anybody about what happened. But... it was just Doc! Doc was trustworthy. Surely, it would be fine if you told him about it- right?</p> <<if Flag("KidnappedByLevi")>>\ <ul>\ <li> [[“Well, I did get kidnapped in the process, but the guy turned out to be cool!” (Excited)|Checkup Kidnapped Working Truth Like Levi]]</li> <li> [[“Well, I did get kidnapped in the process, but I've decided to work with him.” (Reluctant)|Checkup Kidnapped Working Truth Dislike Levi]]</li> <li> [[“Yeah, I've made some progress. I'm working on it.” (Evasive)|Checkup Kidnapped Working Lie]]</li> </ul>\ <<else>>\ <ul>\ <li> [[“Well, I met the guy who was supposed to recieve it, and I'm gonna help him track it down.”|Checkup Working Truth]]</li> <li> [[“I've made some progress... but I don't think I should tell you about it.”|Checkup Working Lie]]</li> </ul>\ <</if>>\ <<else>>\ <p>Uh... yeah. Maybe you were going to have to spill the beans about not working with that guy, Levi, and therefore being at a complete dead end. But, well... maybe you should keep the details to yourself.</p> <<if Flag("KidnappedByLevi")>>\ <ul>\ <li> [[“Well, when I went to that address you told me about, I got kidnapped. So I haven't made much progress, no.” (Honest)|Checkup Kidnapped Truth]]</li> <li> [[“I met the recipient, but he wasn't much help. We'll just have to find another angle.” (Secretive)|Checkup Kidnapped Lie]]</li> </ul>\ <<else>>\ <ul>\ <li> [[“Well, I met the guy who was supposed to recieve it, but he seemed... off. I think it's better if we go this alone.”|Checkup None Truth]]</li> </ul>\ <</if>>\ <</if>>\<p>"Kidnapped? I'm sorry, <<print $player.name>>, you were //kidnapped// when you went to talk to the recipient?" This clearly alarmed him, as it probably should. "How are you being so blasé about this?!"</p> <p>With a shrug and an eye roll, you muttered, "Yeah, yeah, I was kidnapped.<<if Flag("LostFinger")>> And he cut my finger off, too.<</if>> But really, it's fine! He's a nice guy. I think you'd like him."</p> <p>Doc stopped in his tracks, standing in the middle of the busiest street in The Stacks, forcing you to stop with him. "<<if Flag("LostFinger")>>He //cut your finger off//?<<else>>He //kidnapped you//?<</if>> And you //like// him?"</p> <p>"Seriously, it was just a misunderstanding. We're fine. I'm gonna help him track down that cargo!"</p> * [[He doesn't seem very amenable to the idea.|Checkup Doc Disapproves]] <<SetFlag "KidnappingApologist">>\ <<SetFlag "DocKnowsAboutKidnapping">>\ <<set $temp3 = true>>\ <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(-20)>>\<p>"Kidnapped? I'm sorry, <<print $player.name>>, you were //kidnapped// when you went to talk to the recipient?" This clearly alarmed him, as it probably should. "Are you okay?"</p> <p>You pursed your lips. "I'm fine. It was a little scary, but I'm fine."</p> <p>"And let me get this straight. You're working with the man who kidnapped you?" This entire situation had him looking at you with the most incredulous, wide-eyed stare.</p> <p>"He's going to pay me if I help him track down this cargo. I need the cash, and this is my best chance to figure out who shot me."</p> * [[He doesn't seem very amenable to the idea.|Checkup Doc Disapproves]] <<SetFlag "DocKnowsAboutKidnapping">>\<p>"Excellent," Doc announced, his smile widening. "What sort of progress? Did meeting with the recipient give you some more clues?"</p> <p>Oh, yeah. Of course. He was going to want to know about the investigation. And you had to //not// tell him. This felt... bad. After collecting your thoughts for a moment, you muttered, "I think I'm going to do he rest of this alone, Doc. Appreciate your help, but I'd rather not get you involved."</p> <p>The smile left his face in an instant. "Oh... yes. I understand." He didn't. "If you don't want me getting involved with your business, I'm okay with that." He wasn't. Doc had been very excited to help you with this. And you couldn't even explain why... damn, now you felt like a real asshole.</p> <p>"I can let you know when I've figured it out! I just have to do it alone."</p> * [[He nods, resolving to just move on.|Checkup Sad Ending]]<p>"Oh, that's great. So he told you what the cargo was?"</p> <p>"Uh..." You hesitated for a moment. "No, not quite. I think it's supposed to be, like, top secret."</p> <p>Doc seemed a little confused. "Okay... did he have any ideas of who might have stolen it?"</p> <p>"If he did, he hasn't told me yet."</p> <p>"Okay. Do you still need help with it?" His grin had slowly turned into a nervous little smile- evidently, he was disappointed by the direction your search had taken you in.</p> <p>To be fair... yeah, you hadn't gotten very much information out of Levi. But you were also pretty explicitly told that this was meant to be secret. So letting Doc in on everything would probably be a bad idea. "I think I've gotta do the rest of this alone."</p> <p>"Oh. Yes. Okay."</p> <p>"I can let you know when we've figured it out."</p> * [[He nods, resolving to just move on.|Checkup Sad Ending]]<p>Doc furrowed his brow, analyzing your face, trying to figure you out. "Why's that, <<print $player.name>>?"</p> <p>"I'm going to be helping the guy who hired me to track it down, but it's a big secret. I don't want to break his trust or anything."</p> <p>"Oh... yes. That makes sense." Despite the words coming out of his mouth, it was clear that he was disappointed. This was probably the most exciting thing to happen to him in a while, and you'd just written him out of the story. "If you do need any help, you know who to ask."</p> <p>"Of course, Doc," you muttered, although you knew for a fact that this wasn't going to happen. "I'll let you know."</p> * [[He nods, resolving to just move on.|Checkup Sad Ending]]<p>"Kidnapped? I'm sorry, <<print $player.name>>, you were //kidnapped// when you went to talk to the recipient?" This clearly alarmed him, as it probably should. "Are you okay? That's very serious!"</p> <p>You pursed your lips. "I'm fine. It was a little scary, but I'm fine. The guy just asked me a bunch of questions and then let me go."</p> <p>"This investigation might be a little too dangerous to be embarking on so casually." He rested a hand on your shoulder as you walked. "I don't want you getting hurt again. Whatever you've gotten yourself wrapped up in, it's clearly bigger than I thought."</p> <p>"But bigger means more cash, right?" The idea was still exciting you. If Levi was willing to kidnap a random stranger to figure out where that cargo was, it was probably worth a fucking fortune. At least to somebody. "Frankly, I don't really care if the asshole who kidnapped me gets his shit back. But if we track it down... that could be a lot of money."</p> <p>Doc's hand left your shoulder, almost like instinct, and slid into the pocket where his payout was hidden. Money... in Signal Hill, especially for a guy like Doc, that was a big deal. "Okay. Yeah. Stealing from thieves and kidnappers isn't the most morally questionable thing I've ever done. Let's do it."</p> * [[And so you started your strategizing.|Checkup Strategizing]] <<SetFlag "DocKnowsAboutKidnapping">>\<p>"That's unfortunate." Doc's smile faded, and then after a moment of silence, his brow furrowed. "Another angle?"</p> <p>"Y'know, like... if we find it ourselves and get it back for him, we can probably get a reward or something." This was complete bullshit, of course- if it was expensive, you were going to sell it, hands down. You weren't dealing with that Levi creep again if you could help it. But without spilling the beans about your kidnapping, Doc probably wasn't going to go along with a theft like that.</p> <p>"Oh, yes. Money would be... useful." Doc's hand, almost like instinct, slid into the pocket where his payout was hidden. Money... in Signal Hill, especially for a guy like Doc, that was a big deal. "My, <<print $player.name>>, this is exciting! It's like I'm the dapper detective Sherlock, and you're Dr. Watson! Or... maybe the other way round, come to think of it."</p> <p>Chuckling, you muttered, "I think we're gonna make a good team, Doc."</p> * [[And so you started your strategizing.|Checkup Strategizing]]<p>Doc furrowed his brow. "Off? In what way?"</p> <p>"I... can't even really explain it. He gave off some really uncomfortable energy, and he was very insistent about wanting to know what happened. I think he might be up to something." It was hard to communicate what was so //wrong// about this interaction, but you felt it deep inside you. Doc would just have to trust you. "Oh, and he wouldn't fucking pay me."</p> <p>"Okay. I think I understand. So then what's the plan?"</p> <p>You shrugged. "Well, if we find it ourselves, we could probably get a reward for handing it over. Or I guess sell it off. Either way, we could get a good paycheck out of it."</p> <p>"Oh, yes. Money would be... useful." Doc's hand, almost like instinct, slid into the pocket where his payout was hidden. Money... in Signal Hill, especially for a guy like Doc, that was a big deal. "My, <<print $player.name>>, this is exciting! It's like I'm the dapper detective Sherlock, and you're Dr. Watson! Or... maybe the other way round, come to think of it."</p> <p>Chuckling, you muttered, "I think we're gonna make a good team, Doc."</p> * [[And so you started your strategizing.|Checkup Strategizing]]<p><<if $temp3 == true>>Doc started walking again, shaking his head. <</if>>"Look... I don't exactly //approve// of this. I know, I'm not your dad. But I want to make it very clear that I think this is a bad idea."</p> <p>"I can handle myself. I'll be fine."</p> <p>He glanced at where the hole in your side used to be, silent. He didn't need to say anything to make the message clear. And you didn't appreciate his implication, but you also couldn't deny that he was right.</p> <<include "Checkup Sad Ending">><p>The two of you walked back down to the clinic in relative silence. The sun was still violently hot, and warm sweat beaded up on your brow. Even Doc eventually shrugged his jacket off and threw it over his shoulder, careful with the pocket that contained his cash.</p> <p>When you arrived at the door to the clinic, Doc put his hand on the handle, stopped, and turned to you. "Now, if you don't mind, I have some work to do in the lab." His voice was drained. "It was nice getting to speak with you again. I'm... glad you're getting settled."</p> * [[“It was nice. We should do this again sometime.”|Checkup Finish]] * [[“I'll see you around.”|Checkup Finish]]<p>The two of you arrived back at the clinic soon enough. The sun was still violently hot, and warm sweat beaded up on your brow. Even Doc eventually shrugged his jacket off and threw it over his shoulder, careful with the pocket that contained his cash.</p> <p>"How about you come back to my office, and we can start planning the next steps of our... //investigation//." He was beaming, excited for this little mystery you were going to solve together. "Unless you have somewhere else to be..."</p> * [[“Hell no, let's go get started!”|Checkup Office][$relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)]] * [[“Nah, it's fine, we can get started now.”|Checkup Office]]<p>You waved to Joyette on your way past and huddled back into Doc's office, shutting the door behind you. It was barely cooler in here. You collapsed back on the leather couch. Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance was perched on the arm of the couch, upside down, open to a spot about 3/4 of the way through. There was a cup of half finished coffee languishing on the side table, probably quite cold by now.</p> <p>"Okay. Let's get our facts straight." Doc retrieved a leatherbound journal off the bookshelf and a pen from his desk before joining you on the couch. Flipping it open to the front page, he wrote down in nearly unreadable script, 'MISSING CARGO.' Then he looked over to you expectantly. "Where should we start?"</p> * [[“Let's just record all the evidence we have so far.”|Checkup Evidence]]<p>Doc started jotting down a few basic facts, recounting to you what he was writing as he went. The gear that the assailants were wearing, the weapons they used, the bullet calibre. "How many boxes was it, again?"</p> <p>"Just one."</p> <p>He nodded as he scrawled that down as well. "Dimensions?"</p> <p>"Uhh... about 7 feet long, 2 feet tall, 3 feet wide."</p> <p>"That's all?" Doc tapped his pen to his lip, brow furrowed in curiosity. "I knew it was small, but that's an odd size. Especially for such a distance."</p> * [[“You're right. It's pretty weird.”|Checkup More Evidence]] * [[“That just means it's valuable.”|Checkup More Evidence]]<p>Flipping to a new page, Doc muttered, "<<if Flag("DocKnowsAboutKidnapping")>>While it's unfortunate that you were kidnapped, that also means we've got some new information, right?<<else>>Now that you've met with the man who was meant to receive this cargo, we've got some new information, right?<</if>>"</p> <p>"Oh, yeah." The thought hadn't even crossed your mind. This could be invaluable for discovering the nature of the shipment and who stole it. "Yeah, that's a great point."</p> <p>He put pen to paper. "So? What was he like?"</p> * [[“Well, his name was Levi.”|Checkup Levi Reveal][$temp4 = "name"]] * [[“He had a whole lot of tattoos.”|Checkup Levi Reveal][$temp4 = "tattoos"]] * [[“He was a Northerner.”|Checkup Levi Reveal][$temp4 = "north"]]<<if $temp4 == "name">>\ <p>"Levi?" Doc's eyes snapped up from the paper, suddenly staring you down with an unexpectedly grave expression. "Tell me- did he have scars on his face?"</p> <p>"Uh... yes, yes he did. You know him?"</p> <<elseif $temp4 == "tattoos">>\ <p>"What sort of tattoos?"</p> <p>You shrugged. "Northerner tattoos. Plants, patterns. And a lot of scars."</p> <p>Doc's eyes snapped up from the paper, suddenly staring you down with an unexpectedly grave expression. "Tell me- was his name Levi?"</p> <p>That was... concerning. "Yeah, it was. You know him?"</p> <<elseif $temp4 == "north">>\ <p>Furrowing his brow, he asked, "How do you know that?"</p> <p>"Oh, it was pretty obvious from the decor. And he had some scars and tattoos you'd only ever see up North."</p> <p>Doc's eyes snapped up from the paper, suddenly staring you down with an unexpectedly grave expression. "Tell me- was his name Levi?"</p> <p>That was... concerning. "Yeah, it was. You know him?"</p> <</if>>\ <p>He went silent, his gaze growing distant. Calculating. As if you weren't even in the room with him. He slowly lifted his hand to his face, placing the end of his pen between his teeth and biting down on it. "I've sold to him before. Strange man. Almost certainly associated with a cult."</p> * [[“'Sold to him'? Sold what?”|Checkup Sold]] * [[“Cult? What cult?”|Checkup Cult]]<p>For a moment, he was silent. Trying to pick his words. "Pharmaceuticals. A very rare one, with psychotropic effects. I suspect they're using it for some kind of ritual purpose." Shaking his head, Doc started furiously writing notes down in his unreadable handwriting. "That's not important, though. If he is associated with this cult, this situation could be very big- and very bad."</p> <<include "Checkup Nouveau">><p>"A cult that operates out of Signal Hill- or at least used to. They've been quiet for months." Shaking his head, Doc started furiously writing notes down in his unreadable handwriting. "If this cargo was going to them, it could be something very important. And very bad."</p> <<include "Checkup Nouveau">><p>"Hang on, you're gonna have to rewind there." All this cult nonsense was confusing you, big time. "Start from the beginning. Who are these people?"</p> <p>"I don't think they have an official name," he muttered, his voice low as if in reverence. "At least if they do, it's not public. They're quite secretive. I know they follow the so-called //corps nouveau//."</p> <p>Having grown up in the North, you'd gotten a pretty good understanding of French- it was used for pretty much all religious purposes, and often spoken in everyday life right alongside English. <<if $identity.includes("devotee")>>This particular phrase, though, reminded you of some of your more esoteric studies. It was an obvious play on the //corps divin//, the divine body. Not a concept the everyday saint venerating public would be familiar with. The body of God, decaying since the world came to an end, suffusing the world with its divinity. And //nouveau//. New. "The new body... of God?"<<else>>//Nouveau//, new. //Corps//, body. "The new body?"<</if>></p> <p>"A cult leader. Very... unsettling. Always covers their face."</p> <p>"And... Levi's part of that?" To be fair, he was pretty //intense//. Had a bit of a cult vibe.</p> <p>Doc shrugged. "I don't have any definitive proof, it's not like he told me. But they definitely use this particular drug for rituals, and he definitely purchased significant quantities of it from me."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“So we could be getting ourselves into a mess right now.”|Checkup Dangerous]]</li> <<if $identity.includes("hedonist")>>\ <li> [[“Hold up... could you tell me more about these drugs? That sounds sick.”|Checkup Hedonist]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if Flag("ThinksItsDrugs")>>\ <li> [[“So that only adds to my theory that there are drugs in the box. Excellent.”|Checkup Drug Box]]</li> <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>Doc sighed, leaning back further into the couch and furrowing his brow. "Not necessarily. The past few months, they've been completely silent. They might have disbanded, moved, their leader might have been killed."</p> <p>"But if Levi's still around, they must still be around."</p> <p>"Maybe. But in a reduced capacity, at least." Absently, he fetched the cup of cold coffee off the coffee table and took a long sip before placing it back down. Nasty. "<<if Flag("DocIsAThief")>>As long as we're careful, we still have the excuse that you're just looking to return the cargo.<<else>>All we're doing is trying to return the cargo. Surely they'll be... lenient.<</if>>"</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Okay, so let's get our theories in order.”|Checkup Theories]]</li> </ul>\<p>"I would rather not tell you anything about these drugs," Doc snapped. His tone had shifted entirely, in just the span of a moment. "This isn't fun and games. I'm talking about serious- and seriously dangerous- substances."</p> <p>That... didn't deter you. It didn't deter you at all. Whatever this was, getting your hands on it was now goal numero uno.</p> <p>"Sorry, jeez. I didn't realize it was such a big deal."</p> <p>Doc shook his head, like a dog shaking water off its fur. "I'm sorry, I shouldn't be so rude. It's just not something I want you getting involved in."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Let's just start going over our theories.”|Checkup Theories]]</li> </ul>\<p>"As far as I know, this particular //substance// is only native to this region. I don't think it's possible to acquire it where you're from. Unless it was shipped the other way around."</p> <p>Uh... no. Your theory still totally made sense. "They could have shipped it up North, and then back South?"</p> <p>"And why would they do that?"</p> <p>Silence. "Fair enough. Must be a different drug, then. If they're taking one drug, they're probably taking other ones too."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Let's just start going over our theories.”|Checkup Theories]]</li> </ul>\<p>Doc flipped to a new page and tapped his pen to the lined paper. "Drugs? Is drugs our main theory? Is it drugs?"</p> <<if Flag("ThinksItsDrugs")>>\ <p>"I think drugs might be our only theory." You were pretty fucking confident that it was drugs.</p> <p>Rather than his usual unreadable cursive, Doc slowly printed out the word "DRUGS" across the whole page in big, scratchy lines with his pen. "Sounds right to me. Let's get to the plan, then." He shut the notebook and tossed it over on the coffee table.</p> <<set $temp6 = true>>\ <ul>\ <li> [[“I think that means we're ready to start planning!”|Checkup Next Steps]]</li> </ul>\ <<else>>\ <p>"It could definitely be drugs. Especially since you said they use drugs for rituals and stuff. Maybe something rare, something you can only get up North?"</p> <p>Doc stared at you for a moment, as if waiting for you to speak. And he kept staring just a little to long. "So? Did you have a specific drug in mind?"</p> <p>Oh. Yeah. You're also from the North. "<<if $identity.includes("hedonist")>>Uh... no, honestly, I don't think there's anything like that. I'm pretty sure I would have tried it.<<else>>Uh... gonna be honest, I don't know much about drugs. There's probably //something//, right?<</if>>"</p> <p>He frowned. "It could be. I'm far from confident in it, though. Got any other ideas?"</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“What if it's some kind of technology?”|Checkup Technology]]</li> <li> [[“What if it's some kind of religious relic?”|Checkup Relic]]</li> </ul>\ <</if>>\<p>"One of the guys I was with swore that he heard some kind of static coming from inside the box. I don't know what kind of machine it would be, but if they transported it all the way down here, it could be super valuable."</p> <p>Doc nodded along as you spoke, jotting down little notes about your idea. "I really like that theory. Admittedly, I'm not sure why a cult would need a giant machine like that... but it makes sense with the rest of the evidence, at least."</p> <p>"But who would steal that?"</p> <p>"I don't think we have any way of narrowing down their intentions. Maybe we just need a list of suspects first."</p> * [[“Okay. Who has big guns, good armour, and enough men?”|Checkup Suspects]]<p>"They're a cult, after all. Separated from their homeland. Religious relics are incredibly important up North, and acquiring them and bringing them down here could be important to their beliefs in some way."</p> <p>Doc nodded along as you spoke, jotting down little notes about your idea. "Yes, it does make a lot of sense. I'm not sure why anybody in Signal Hill would want to steal them, though. The motive is just not here."</p> <p>"You don't think so? I've already met tons of Northerners down here." You shrugged. "It feels like there are plenty of people with around who'd want to steal something like that."</p> <p>"Maybe we need a list of suspects before we start trying to identify their motives."</p> * [[“Okay. Who has big guns, good armour, and enough men?”|Checkup Suspects]]<p>Doc immediately scribbled down a few unreadable words. "There are really only three possibilities."</p> <p>"Only three?" That was a great place to start.</p> <p>"It could be a gang, of course. The only gang leader in the area with that kind of firepower would be Jett.<<if $leads.includes("testrun") or $playedleads.includes("testrun")>>" Jett- you'd heard that name before. KC called out his gang as one of the ones holed up in The Graveyard. "<<else>> <</if>>It could also be mercenaries, hired on by some rich client- you're familiar with the Lamplighters. This would be within their capabilities, easily."</p> <p>You nodded. All of that made sense. "And the third?"</p> <p>Gritting his teeth, Doc pointed with the tip of his pen to the final entry on his list of suspects- a word you couldn't read, given his illegible cursive. "The militia. We don't want this one." His voice was grave, tinged with an almost reverent concern.</p> * [[“Why not?”|Checkup Militia]] * [[“Do I want to know?”|Checkup Militia]]<p>"I don't think you've really encountered the militia yet. Be thankful for that." Doc leaned forward, resting his forearms on his knees, staring off at the opposite wall with a distant look on his face. Remembering. "That abandoned building across the street, it used to be where The Lamplighters operated from. Until the militia raided them a few years back. There were no warnings given, no orders to leave the city, no arrest warrants. The law hadn't even been changed yet. They showed up with guns one morning and killed three men."</p> <p>"That's... rough."</p> <p>"I transported their bodies to the crematory. One of them was shot in the head at point blank. The other two were shot in the back."</p> <p>You nodded gravely. "So we really don't want it to be the militia."</p> <p>"On the plus side," he muttered, straightening himself out, "it's probably not them. They would fit the physical description, but the circumstances just don't make sense. They could, legally, seize your cargo at the checkpoint. They wouldn't need to do any of this."</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“We're not going to figure this out by just thinking about it. We need a plan.”|Checkup Next Steps]]</li> </ul>\<p><<if not $temp6 == true>>Doc flipped his notebook closed and tossed it over on the coffee table, where it slid to a stop next to his stale coffee. <</if>>"What I've determined from all of this is that we need a hell of a lot more evidence before we can track anything down."</p> <p>"Agreed. I'm not certain of anything yet.<<if Flag("ThinksItsDrugs")>> Except the fact that it's definitely drugs.<</if>>"</p> <p>"There are a couple places we could start. You could ask around, see if anybody's heard any rumours. If we can figure out what all of those suspects are up to, we'd be in luck. And the rumour mill in Signal Hill... well, it's active." Doc pursed his lips, thinking for a moment. "I suppose you could also go back to the scene of the crime and see if there's any evidence we've missed. I didn't have the time to do an investigation, given that you were at risk of bleeding out. There could still be something out there that tells us exactly where this cargo was taken. In the meantime, I can ask around my contacts."</p> <p>That was as good a place as any to get started. In fact, better. That was an excellent place to get started! "Doc, I think this is gonna be the start of a beautiful partnership. We make for great detectives."</p> <p>He cracked a wide grin. "Maybe hold off on that until we've actually done investigative work, hm? Now if you don't mind, I have something to take care of in the lab."</p> * [[And with that, you had your Watson at last!|Checkup Finish]] <<addlead "csisignalhill" "CSI Signal Hill">>\ <<addlead "whisperingstreets" "Whispering Streets">>\ <<set $whisperingstreets = []>>\ <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(15)>>\<h1>"""----""" STORY COMPLETE """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CONTINUE|Clinic Hub]]</h5> <<completelead "checkup">>\ <<unset $temp>>\ <<unset $temp1>>\ <<unset $temp2>>\ <<unset $temp3>>\ <<unset $temp4>>\ <<unset $temp5>>\ <<unset $temp6>>\ <<set $chapter = 2>>\<h1>"""----""" NEW STORY """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CONSULTATION|Consult Knock]]</h5><p>You rapped your knuckles against the sturdy door, startling Joyette a little as she clearly hadn't noticed your approach. There was a long pause, and for a second you wondered if you should maybe knock again. The music wasn't that loud. But who knows. Maybe he was hard of hearing. Y'know, lots of people neglect ear protection when they get into gunfights.</p> <p>Before you could make a decision, though, the door swung open. Doc was wearing a cozy black turtleneck sweater, his hair tied back into a low bun and a pair of delicate wireframe glasses sitting low on his nose. In his hand, a pristine copy of Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, his thumb keeping his place about halfway through. "Ah, <<print $player.name>>. You're feeling better?"</p> * [[“Yeah, I've gotten the lay of the land and healed up and I think I'm ready to look into that cargo.”|Consult Ready][$temp to "healed"]] * [[“No... I'm just impatient as fuck and I really want to track down that cargo.”|Consult Ready][$temp to "impatient"]] * [[“...you wear glasses?”|Consult Ready][$temp to "glasses"]] * [[“Yeah, I just wanted to chat with you.”|Consult Ready][$temp to "chat"]]<<if $temp == "healed">>\ <p>"Good to hear. You've recovered surprisingly well from that surgery." He moved aside, gesturing to invite you into his office. <<if $leads.includes("consultation")>>"Come, let's discuss those papers of yours."<<else>>"Come, I have something to show you regarding the cargo that was stolen from you."<</if>></p> <<elseif $temp == "impatient">>\ <p>Doc was silent for a moment. "I... appreciate your honesty. Well, since you're already here, we might as well discuss <<if $leads.includes("consultation")>>those papers of yours<<else>>the documentation you had on you when you were shot. I've found some interesting things out from them<</if>>." He moved aside, gesturing to invite you into his office.</p> <<elseif $temp == "glasses">>\ <p>Doc raised an eyebrow, lifting a finger to push his spectacles further up his nose. "Reading glasses, yes." He moved aside, gesturing to invite you into his office. "<<if $leads.includes("consultation")>>You came to discuss the papers I found, no?<<else>>Since you're here, I'd like to show you something interesting I found out about your cargo.<</if>> How about you come inside."</p> <<elseif $temp == "chat">>\ <p>"Oh. That's... very nice of you." Doc seemed almost flustered by the idea that someone would want to chat with him. He presumably didn't have many interactions like this. "<<if $leads.includes("consultation")>>About the documents I found, yes?<<else>>Well, since you're here, I have something I'd like to show you. About your stolen cargo.<</if>> How about you come inside."</p> <</if>>\ <p>Stepping past him, you were immediately aware that this was far from a conventional office. There was a desk, for sure, an old wooden thing tucked off to the right scattered with medical texts, paperwork, and now your bloody documents. A microscope and some other inscrutable scientific tech was lined up on metal shelves next to it, alongside bleached animal skulls and specimen jars with unknown contents. That wasn't where Doc had been sitting, though- instead it was clear he had been cozied up on an overstuffed loveseat in the back corner. On a coffee table in front of it was a mug of something still steaming, and a record player slowly calling out the scratchy sound of piano music. His book must have been retrieved from the shelf beside it, which was piled high with mostly medical textbooks and a few ancient works of classic literature.</p> <p>There were two doors in this room, to the left and right respectively. One was ajar and led into a small darkened hallway, presumably where Doc's bedroom and private washroom would be. Next to it, the overcoat, rifle, and wide brimmed hat he'd worn when he found you were hung up on a coat rack. The bird shaped gas mask was nowhere to be seen- maybe he kept that in a place of honour. On the oposite wall, though, was a far more intimidating sight than any sniper rifle. A sturdy door, fitted with several ominous padlocks, with the word "LAB" stencilled on it in plack paint.</p> * [[“This is a really nice little office, Doc.”|Consult Nice]] * [[“This place really screams 'a nerd lives here.'”|Consult Nerd]] * [[“What the fuck is in that lab?”|Consult Lab]] <<unset $temp>>\<p>You could see in real time as Doc considered your compliment, evaluated it for sarcasm, and then brightened up. "Thank you! I do what I can with the resources we have. This is my home, I try to take care of it." There was so much pride in his voice. It was almost heartwarming.</p> <p>"You aren't here to see my decorating, though," he corrected himself, snapping back into doctor mode. "I set about evaluating these documents for you. They were partially ruined by blood, but there were copies on each of your companions' bodies, so I was able to piece together a good amount of them."</p> * [[“It shouldn't be anything groundbreaking. Just shipping manifests and delivery instructions.”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“Those should have the info about the person recieving the cargo, right?”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“These are... important, somehow?”|Consult Delivery]] <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)>>\<p>Doc bristled at your comment and turned away, facing towards the desk as if to hide his expression of annoyance from you. "Yes, I suppose that is accurate. Can we discuss these papers?"</p> <p>"Yeah, let's talk about the papers." You very nearly called him a nerd again, but caught yourself just before.</p> <p>"I set about evaluating them earlier. They were partially ruined by blood, but there were copies on each of your companions' bodies, so I was able to piece together a good amount of them."</p> * [[“It shouldn't be anything groundbreaking. Just shipping manifests and delivery instructions.”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“Those should have the info about the person recieving the cargo, right?”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“These are... important, somehow?”|Consult Delivery]] <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(-5)>>\<p>Doc gave you a confused look for a moment, before glancing over at the door and nodding his head. "Ah, yes. I suppose the lab does look suspicious. I can reassure you that the locks are for keeping people out, not for keeping anything in." He didn't elaborate any further, let alone answer the question. Doctor stuff, presumably.</p> <p>"Now, about your stolen goods," he continued, trying to get back on track. "I set about evaluating those documents for you. They were partially ruined by blood, but there were copies on each of your companions' bodies, so I was able to piece together a good amount of them."</p> * [[“It shouldn't be anything groundbreaking. Just shipping manifests and delivery instructions.”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“Those should have the info about the person recieving the cargo, right?”|Consult Delivery]] * [[“These are... important, somehow?”|Consult Delivery]]<p>"Exactly." He pulled out the chair, an old black office-looking thing made of cheap plastic and fake leather, and took a seat at his desk. Collecting the papers and scooping them up in his hands, he angled them so that you could see while looking over his shoulder. The pages were warped and stained dark brown with blood, having dried crusty and close to crumbling in the desert air. The ink was smudged. You couldn't make out anything. "I couldn't decipher anything about the payment or recipient, but there were some interesting things in there."</p> <p>Placing a hand on the back of the chair and leaning in to get a closer look, you still couldn't figure out what anything said. Except the letterhead. But "DELTA CARAVANS" didn't help you much. They were just a shipping company based up North, and you, just one of their contractors.</p> <p>"What kind of interesting things?"</p> <p>Doc started to shuffle through the pages, each more ruined than the last, with only tiny fragments untouched by blood or the elements. "Well, I learned a bit about the cargo, figured out who the sender was, and determined the address you were meant to deliver it to."</p> * [[“Tell me about the cargo.”|Consult Cargo]] * [[“Tell me about the sender.”|Consult Sender]] * [[“What's the address?”|Consult Address]]<p>"Well, it wasn't evaluated by the shipping company. They have a specific stamp for that, apparently." He shuffled to the correct page and pointed out a faded stamp in black ink that just barely read, "NO SEARCH CONDUCTED."</p> <p>"So... they didn't vet it? Why?"</p> <p>Doc shrugged. "You would know better than me. I would assume that the sender requested it not be opened."</p> <p>You racked your brain for information about this. Things you had picked up from working shipping, from friends and lovers in the industry, from long nights on the road.</p> <ul>\ <<if $identity.includes("nomad")>>\ <li> [[Finally, memorizing all of those company policies could come in handy...|Consult Savvy Success]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[You don't know much about this industry, actually.|Consult Dont Know]]</li> <li> <<link "You must know something. <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-brain'></i>">><<savvyroll 6 "Consult Savvy Success" "Consult Savvy Failure">><</link>></li>\ <</if>>\ </ul>\ <<set $tempcargo = true>>\ <<set $temppocket = false>>\<p>Just then, the memory came to you, a flicker of a connection blossoming into a realization. The companies up North, most of them abided by the religious mores of their communities, and sometimes that was codified in official rules. In particular, it was consideded sacrilege to view religious artifacts- saintly relics, blessed objects. It diminished their power, through knowing them. The same reason why the augurs of the North covered their faces. The shipping company probably had a policy of not checking cargo that was reasonably agreed to contain sacred items.</p> <p>You relayed this revelation to Doc, and he sat in silence, considering it for a moment. "Okay. So either the cargo was some kind of religious item, or the sender //claimed// that it was religious in nature to avoid having it searched. That doesn't necessarily narrow it down... but it's interesting."</p> <p>"Why would anyone down here murder four people to steal religious artifacts from the North?"</p> <p>He contemplated the question. "I don't know... you're a Northerner. Any ideas?"</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Relics tend to be expensive- you could probably make a tidy profit off of selling them off.”|Consult Expensive]]</li>\ <li> [[“Devotees often quibble about how to properly treat our relics. It could be a contentious item.”|Consult Quibble]]</li>\ <<if $identity.includes("devotee")>>\ <li> [[“Our holy items hold great power, especially saintly relics. Anyone would be overcome with greed.”|Consult Relics]]</li>\ <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>You thought about it for a moment, but only long enough to get on your own nerves. What did you think you were, some kind of shipping expert? You were a contractor. You did this job once, maybe a few times maximum. What the fuck did you know about this goddamn industry?</p> <p>"Fuck, I don't know," you finally admitted. "Maybe they paid extra for it? Or they were like, a trusted customer? I have no clue."</p> <p>"Those are all pretty valid hypotheses. But not quite. This situation is... puzzling." <<include "Consult Speculation">></p><p>You put all of your (limited) mental effort into it, straining to figure out what this set of information could possibly mean. Sealed box... being secretively delivered long distances... <<if $tempsender == true>>from a laboratory... <</if>>and marked to not be inspected...</p> <p>"It's drugs. It's gotta be drugs!" You were a genius.</p> <p>"Drugs?"</p> <p>"Y'know, some kind of drug smuggling operation," you argued, suddenly very convinced of your own argument. "They must have, like, somebody on the inside with the company to mark it like that. So the drugs aren't discovered."</p> <p>Doc cleared his throat. "I don't think we have any major drug smuggling operations running from the North down to Signal Hill, <<print $player.name>>."</p> <p>"How do //you// know?" It was a rhetorical question, but also kind of a valid question. How //would// he know?</p> <<include "Consult Speculation">> <<SetFlag "ThinksItsDrugs">>\"I suppose. But that would require your assailants to know the contents of the delivery and the value therein, which, if they were local, is puzzling." <<include "Consult Speculation">>"I suppose. But who would escalate such a conflict to the scale of hiring heavily armed mercenaries to kill the caravaneers escorting it? That part is puzzling." <<include "Consult Speculation">>"I suppose if that was your belief you might do a lot to obtain that power. Or keep it away from someone you don't like. But how did they track down your caravan and know what was inside? It's puzzling." <<include "Consult Speculation">>Shaking his head, Doc murmured, "None of this speculation will make any sense unless you figure out who the cargo was for and who stole it. You should focus on that, if this is important to you." It was clear from the way he spoke that it was important to him too. It was just that- puzzling. A brain teaser. One that led to you getting a bullet in your abdomen, but a brain teaser nonetheless. He'd gotten invested. Surely, this was more exciting than administering naloxone to the latest overdose patient. <ul>\ <<if $tempsender isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Okay. Then tell me about the sender.”|Consult Sender]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if $tempaddress isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Okay. Then give me the address and I'll figure that out.”|Consult Address]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[“I think I've got what I need.”|Consult Got It]]</li>\ <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>"Well, I don't know //exactly// who the sender was, but I know their place of work at least. The business that filed the paperwork was called 'Sigma Biolabs.' I couldn't determine if this was sent in an official capacity by that company or by one of its employees." Doc tapped the side of his glasses, considering the highly smudged text around the name deeply. "The name obviously implies this could have been some kind of research... but why it would be delivered here, or stolen, isn't obvious."</p> <p>You almost couldn't pay attention to his speculation, because that name buzzed in you head and filled your ears with snow and your nose with the smell of cigarettes. You could feel that name resonating in your breastbone and digging under your fingernails. Sigma Biolabs... you knew it. You'd been there. You were feeling that memory in your bones.</p> <ul>\ <li> <<link "Try to remember. <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-four'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-four'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-broadcast-tower'></i>">><<signalroll 8 "Consult Signal Success" "Consult Signal Failure">><</link>></li> </ul>\ <<set $tempsender = true>>\ <<set $temppocket = false>><p>The sweet smell of decaying flesh in your nostrils, cut by bleach. "No refridgeration," a person in sanitary robes and kitchen gloves said to another who was their twin, their voice distant and warped like a record playing underwater. They were standing over the metal table, their scalpel pressed against cold skin. "I know it was a lot of money, but this is just ridiculous."</p> <p>"Do what you can." The scalpel split the skin on the opposite side and then down through an artery. A machine whirred to life where the other was standing, loud and violent like a blender. There was a tube leading from it to the table, slipped inside a hole in flesh. As the machine ran, coagulated blood was forced out of the scalpel's cut. Sprays of water diluted it and sent it cascading down the metal table. The water was loud against the metal, like static in your ears, like you were watching this all unfold on the television. A morbid tape, a snuff film of sorts.</p> <p>"I'm not saying it's impossible, we just can't guarantee it. Are we still getting paid if we can't deliver what he's asking for?" The voice was still muffled, and you realized why- they were each clad in these masks, these big clear plastic things that sealed to their faces and filtered the air through spinning disks.</p> <p>"//We're// getting paid no matter what. I'm not concerned with whether the company gets paid." The figure stepped away from the machine, looming over their work. "You've done this a million times. This one is no different."</p> <p>The signal was fading, the lines getting blurry. "There is something very different about this one." It was fuzzy, distant, and then once again you were watching over Doc's shoulder as he pawed through the documents. "So perhaps this could be some kind of corporate sabotage," he proffered, clearly continuing from some point you had just missed entirely.</p> * [[“Yeah. Probably corporate sabotage.”|Consult Memory]] * [[“I guess that makes sense.”|Consult Memory]] * [[“I... don't think that's it, no.”|Consult Memory]]<p>The sweet smell of decaying flesh in your nostrils, cut by bleach. "No refridgeration," a person in sanitary robes and kitchen gloves said to another who was their twin, their voice distant and warped like a record playing underwater.</p> <p>"Do what you can." A scalpel spilled coagulated blood, first oozing and then forced from its home, forced out onto the table. Sprays of water diluted it and sent it cascading down the metal table. The water was loud against the metal, like static in your ears, like you were watching this all unfold on the television. A morbid tape, a snuff film of sorts.</p> <p>"-impossible, we just can't-" The voices cut in and out through snow, wavering, difficult to focus on for more than a moment.</p> <p>The memory faded just like that, filtering like ash between your fingers and leaving you watching over Doc's shoulder as he pawed through the documents. "So perhaps this could be some kind of corporate sabotage," he proffered, clearly continuing from some point you had just missed entirely.</p> * [[“Yeah. Probably corporate sabotage.”|Consult Memory]] * [[“I guess that makes sense.”|Consult Memory]] * [[“I... don't think that's it, no.”|Consult Memory]]<p>Turning back to look at you, Doc seemed concerned. Maybe your tone of voice was a little off. A little distant. "Are you feeling lightheaded at all?"</p> <p>"No, I'm okay," you continued, pushing the lingering odour of rotting flesh from your nostrils. This was not a matter for a medical doctor to deal with. Or whatever Doc was.</p> <p>"Okay." He didn't seem to trust you, but he wasn't about to contradict you. "Well, I guess this doesn't do much to resolve anything, but maybe it'll be useful to know. Now, was there anything else?"</p> <ul>\ <<if $tempcargo isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Can you tell me about the cargo?”|Consult Cargo]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if $tempaddress isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Can you give me the address?”|Consult Address]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[“I think I've got what I need.”|Consult Got It]]</li>\ <</if>>\ </ul>\<p>"Well... I'm sure the actual address wouldn't mean much to you, right? You have only just arrived, after all."</p> <p>Doc was probably right about that. You'd travelled enough to know there were as many address systems as there were cities. Some were lacking entirely, others had regimented street names and numbers, yet more focused on landmarks and distances. "Yeah, I can't say I'm familiar with your city's layout just yet," you concurred. "Maybe just write down the directions?"</p> <p>He flipped over a stray piece of paper hanging off the edge of his desk and grabbed a crappy blue pen, getting to work drawing a crude map. It was hard to parse, but after a few landmarks were put down it came into focus. It was near the gray area where Skid Row blended into The Stacks, a little ways towards the East, tucked down a few side streets. His labels, in an unreadable cursive, would probably not be helpful.</p> * [[You'd probably be able to figure it out from there.|Consult Residential]] <<set $tempaddress = true>>\<p>After circling the building and scrawling a lopsided arrow just in case, Doc leaned back in his chair to observe the little map. "Now... something about this is striking me as interesting, and I'm wondering if you've caught it too."</p> <p>You stared at the crude map for a moment. Nothing particularly striking. It was just... a map. "What's interesting?" you finally asked, taking his bait.</p> <p>"I used to live in this area as a child," he muttered, pointing at part of the map with the tip of his pen. "This building is right next to the grocer my father used to frequent. It's not a factory. It's not a business. These are apartments."</p> <p>"Okay." That didn't strike you as particularly interesting.</p> <p>Doc looked up at you, raising an eyebrow. "Who hires a discrete caravan to send cargo to an apartment in a different city?"</p> * [[“Maybe... relatives?”|Consult Relatives]] * [[“Maybe... they bought something?”|Consult Bought]] * [[“Maybe... it's a cover?”|Consult Cover]]<p>"Have you ever hired a caravan to send somebody a letter?" He shook his head, and you realized that it was a rhetorical question. "There are plenty of courier services that run from Signal Hill up North and vice versa. Why hire four guards to escort a package? That's some mighty expensive mail."</p> <p>It was a fair point. The pay for this gig was supposed to be good, too, and delivered upon reciept- meaning that the recipient was the one footing the bill for your services. Very odd. Especially for personal mail.</p> <<include "Consult Suspicious">>\<p>"That would make sense as to why payment was due upon arriving," he reasoned, "but in that case, wouldn't you have explicit instructions to return with a portion of the payment? What did they expect upon arrival?"</p> <p>"We were getting our pay, and that was it. The paperwork was going to be sent back by courier with signatures and shit. No money."</p> <p>Doc shook his head. "So, the sender paid the company and the reciever was going to pay you. That's not a commercial arrangement."</p> <p>He had a fair point. The pay for this gig was supposed to be good, too. Not what you would expect for a commercial delivery job.</p> <<include "Consult Suspicious">>\<p>"That's my running theory," he corroborated, "maybe because I can't make sense of it in any other way. Maybe the recipient is somebody important trying to keep this transaction secretive?"</p> <p>You nodded. That made the most sense out of any of these ideas. <<if Flag("ThinksItsDrugs")>>And it played into your running theory, the drugs thing.<<else>>Not that any of them made much sense.<</if>></p> <<include "Consult Suspicious">>\<p>"Whatever the case, there is certainly something suspicious about this whole transaction." Doc folded up his map and handed it to you over his shoulder. It was on the back of a letter of some kind. He seemed oblivious of this fact, and you weren't going to point it out. Some snooping was always fun.</p> <ul>\ <<if $tempcargo isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Before I go, about that cargo...”|Consult Cargo]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if $tempsender isnot true>>\ <li> [[“Before I go, about the sender...”|Consult Sender]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[“I think I've got what I need.”|Consult Got It]]</li>\ </ul>\ <<if not $temppocket>>\ <<pocket 'Hand Drawn Map' 1>>\ <<set $temppocket = true>>\ <</if>>\<p>Nodding, Doc arranged the bloody documents as nicely as he could, spun around in his chair, and proffered them to you. "I'm sure these aren't useful anymore, but //technically// you're supposed to send them back to the company. So I'll leave them with you." They crinkled as you grabbed them, all warped and dried into place. Nasty.</p> <p>"This is going to be very helpful," you acknowledged. Out of the goodness of his heart, too. Or more accurately, curiosity.</p> <p>That was made all the more apparent as the man stood and started to take off his glasses, murmuring, "You'll let me know when you figure out what happened, right? I'll admit that it's very much intriguing me."</p> * [[“It's really none of your business.”|Consult Rebuff]] * [[“Of course, I'll keep you in the loop.”|Consult Agree]] * [[“I owe it to you, with all the help you've given me.”|Consult Agree]] * [[“If it gives me an excuse to see you again, of course.”|Consult Flirt]] <<set $temppocket = false>>\ <<unset $tempcargo>>\ <<unset $tempsender>>\ <<unset $tempaddress>>\<p>The expression on his face was impossible to read. Anger? Annoyance? Surprise? It was nearly an emotionless mask, and yet the subtle arc of his brows and twitch of his lips conveyed so much bubbling just beneath the surface. "Ah. Yes. I suppose it is none of my business."</p> <p>"I've gotta get going now." You were already eager to head out, but now you were even moreso. You inched towards the door as the piano record slowed to an end. "I'll let you get back to your motorcycle book now. Enjoy." You didn't peg Doc as a biker, but you supposed people are multifaceted.</p> <p>"That's really not what... um. Yes. I will get back to the motorcycle book." Doc glanced over at the tome where it lay on his desk as you stepped through the doorway. And he seemed to snap out of his good mood when it occurred to him that he'd let go of his place. At least 500 pages to sift through.</p> * [[Best to leave him to it.|Consult Finish]] <<if not $temppocket>>\ <<pocket 'Bloody Documents' 1>>\ <<set $temppocket = true>>\ <</if>>\<p>From your limited experience with him, it seemed pretty rare that a smile would cross Doc's face, and even rarer for that smile to be a gentle and authentic one. "Hopefully it's not too difficult to track down that cargo," he encouraged you, smile on his face all gentle and authentic.</p> <p>"Hopefully." You rapped your knuckles on the edge of his desk, a universal symbol of uncertainty that gave you very little reassurance. "I should probably get to that."</p> <p>"In the meantime, remember that you're welcome here whenever you need."</p> <p>You gave him a quick nod and shared his smile. "Okay, I'll let you get back to your motorcycle book now. Enjoy." You didn't peg Doc as a biker, but you supposed people are multifaceted.</p> <p>"That's really not what... um. Yes. I will get back to the motorcycle book." Doc glanced over at the tome where it lay on his desk as you stepped through the doorway. And he seemed to snap out of his good mood when it occurred to him that he'd let go of his place. At least 500 pages to sift through.</p> * [[Best to leave him to it.|Consult Finish]] <<if not $temppocket>>\ <<pocket 'Bloody Documents' 1>>\ <<set $temppocket = true>>\ <</if>>\<<if $relationship.doc gte 55>>\ <p>You had never seen Doc look 'flustered,' so you had very little frame of reference. But that was the best word you could use to describe the way his eyes widened and the edges of his lips piqued up into a tiny nervous smile. Running his hand through his dark hair, he muttered, "Um... yes. I would be happy to see you again. You have been a delightful patient."</p> <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)>>\ <<else>>\ <p>Doc almost winced as the words left your mouth. It was a little insulting. Just a little. "Um, yes. I would be happy to have you back. If you get hurt, of course, speak with Joyette any time." Not him. Joyette. Ouch.</p> <</if>>\ <p>"Well, I've got a paycheck to track down," you told him, a bit of nervous laughter escaping your lips as you backed towards the door. "I should probably, uh... get going now."</p> <p>"Of course. Our doors are always open."</p> <p>You gave him a quick nod. "Okay, I'll let you get back to your motorcycle book now. Enjoy." You didn't peg Doc as a biker, but you supposed people are multifaceted.</p> <p>"That's really not what... um. Yes. I will get back to the motorcycle book." Doc glanced over at the tome where it lay on his desk as you stepped through the doorway. And he seemed to snap out of his good mood when it occurred to him that he'd let go of his place. At least 500 pages to sift through.</p> * [[Best to leave him to it.|Consult Finish]] <<if not $temppocket>>\ <<pocket 'Bloody Documents' 1>>\ <<set $temppocket = true>>\ <</if>>\ <<set $flirt.doc += 1>>\<h1>"""----""" STORY COMPLETE """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CONTINUE|Clinic Hub]]</h5> <<completelead "consultation">>\ <<addlead "trackingnumber" "Tracking Number">>\ <<set $temppocket = false>>\<h1>"""----""" NEW STORY """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CRASH MEDICINE|Crash Wake]]</h5><p>"And it was just <<print $pro.them>>? Nobody else?" A woman's voice, somewhere by your feet. Soft and warm like honey. You couldn't see her, but you could see who she was talking to- by your bedside, facing away, wearing a simple turtleneck and surprisingly clean slacks. Now hatless, he had silky black hair tied back into a neat, low bun, with just a wisp free hovering by his cheek. He had a small stud in his ear, a round gunmetal grey one.</p> <p>"The others were already dead by the time I found them," he responded. Without the mask, you could hear him loud and clear- gentle, but clinical. He spoke with an exact enunciation that would surely make him an excellent radio host, but without enough personality. Maybe he could be an actor in one of those radio plays they put on in The Rapids. Did they have radio plays out here? Surely, with a name like Signal Hill, they must have killer radio plays.</p> * [[Wait, they're talking about you, right?|Crash Ambush]] <<set $met.push("doc", "joyette")>><p>The woman mused, "Must have been an ambush."</p> <p>"Maybe." He paused a moment. "Must be. But the tire marks were so light, and clearly from a pretty small vehicle. Cargo couldn't have been more than, maybe, 200 pounds."</p> <p>"And?"</p> <p>"Who kills four people over 200 pounds of cargo?" He leaned back against your cot, a hand steadying himself against the strange rack of metal you were hooked into. "Especially since it was a 5.56. Your average highwayman out here isn't going to have a rifle like that."</p> <p>"Must be expensive cargo, then."</p> * [[You're finally coming to.|Crash Pain]]<p>What didn't occur to you at first as you lapsed into consciousness was the absence of something expected. Pain. Your midsection was wrapped snugly in bandages, and you could feel the stitches underneath, but the sharp burning sensation was gone. Where you had just recently been opened up by a bullet, you felt only a persistent itch. Come to think of it, even the plastic tube in your arm wasn't hurting, just a strange, urgent pressure.<<if $skill.savvy == 1>> Whatever you were on, it was probably a pretty powerful painkiller. Maybe an opiate.<</if>></p> <p>However groggy you were, though, you were //lucid//. Finally. You could move, you could sit up. You could speak. And you were no longer in an inordinate, debilitating amount of pain. That's a good start.</p> <p>You silently contemplated what to say to your rescuer, to get his attention.</p> * [[“Uhh... I'm awake.”|Crash Reaction]] * [[“Where the fuck am I?”|Crash Reaction]]<p>The man was clearly startled by the sudden noise, and nearly knocked over the IV stand as he tried to maintain his composure. "Ah. Joyette. The patient is awake." He turned around, and you finally got a good look at his face sans mask. He was asian, with a sharp jaw and soft, refined features. A handful of freckles were dotted across his nose and cheeks, barely visible against his light skin. His eyes were a warm brown, but the bags under them were clearly from overwork.</p> <p>As you craned your head up you could barely see the woman, Joyette, as she politely stepped out of the room. "I'll leave you to take care of this, okay?"</p> <p>Now alone in the room, the man crouched down next to your cot. This was the first time you really registered how tall he was, maybe 6'3" or so. Seeing him from below, it never really occurred to you.</p> <p>"You were shot," the man told you, his tone blunt and conversational. You get the sense that bedside manner was't his forte. Or perhaps, this was what the people in this city responded to. "You're in the Signal Hill Free Clinic. The bullet missed most of your major organs but resulted in a lot of bleeding, and some minor damage to your intestines."</p> * [[“Free? So I don't have to pay for this, right?”|Crash Free]] * [[“It felt a lot worse than that.”|Crash Worse]] * [[“The cargo was stolen?”|Crash Stolen]] <<addlead "stolencargo" "Stolen Cargo">>\<p>"I don't accept payment for my work, no." He brushed that loose strand of black hair behind his ear. "It is a bit of a misnomer, though. My colleague, Joyette, employs a sliding scale. But most of our patients fall right at the bottom of that scale." He smiles, as if this is a point of pride for him.</p> <p>"How do you make money if you work for free?" It was mostly a foreign concept for you. Being paid was the bare minimum for working a gig. If you weren't paid, there was no money, and if there was no money, you couldn't eat.</p> <p>The man chuckled at the seemingly innocuous question. "We don't."</p> * [[“Is that just how things work here?”|Crash New]] * [[“That fucking sucks.”|Crash Sucks]] * [[“That's admirable.”|Crash Admirable]]<p>"No," he reassured you in a tone that was more than a little bitter, "things in Signal Hill are rarely free. I think you'll probably figure that out pretty quickly, given how all you had on you was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">><p>"Well, if we charged, you'd be shit out of luck," he informed you. His voice had a much colder affect. "You didn't have anything on you. Just your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">> <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(-10)>>\<p>The man gave you a faint smile. "Well, if only admirable behaviour could buy drugs. Speaking of which." You almost thought he was going to pull some shit on you, the ol' additional fees card. Instead: "You didn't have any cash on you. Just your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">> <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(10)>>\<p>"You were shot with an automatic rifle," he intoned, exactly as matter of fact as before. "Not very bad is relative. You should count your blessings that you're still alive."</p> <p>Lifting your hand up, feeling the tug of the tube in your arm, you muttered, "So how long am I gonna be hooked up here?"</p> <p>"You've recovered quite well so far." He took a look at the blinking screen on one of the monitors, considering it for a moment before continuing. "So long as you're taking some basic precautions to promote healing, I can discharge you in the next few days."</p> * [[“And then where do I go?”|Crash Then]] * [[“Can I just say here a while? Y'all seem nice.”|Crash Nice]] * [[“Is sex, drugs, and violence out of the question with these... precautions?”|Crash Hedonism]]<p>"There's a whole lot of space to get lost in Signal Hill," the doctor mused. "However, that might be a bit... rough. Let's just say the only things you had on you was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">><p>The doctor nodded. "Well, I prefer to keep my beds open. You never know when an emergency will happen around here." Then, a beat, before he continued. "You might not have much of a choice. All you had on you was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">> <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(5)>>\<p>The doctor let out an almost involuntary laugh, shaking his head. "I only ask that you take your antibiotics and avoid strenuous exercise. Violence, though, I would avoid if possible." Then, his face took a somewhat darker cast. "Although, you may have trouble with drugs. All you had on you was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>."</p> <<include "Crash Process">><p>"Yes. Whatever vehicle you were with, it was commandeered by whoever killed your fellow caravaneers." His tone changed a bit, his voice quieter as if inquiring about a secret. "What exactly were you shipping, if you don't mind me asking?"</p> <p>Whether or not you did mind didn't matter. You only had one answer you could give. "I have no clue. It was all handled by the company."</p> <p>"Interesting." He stroked his chin, glancing up at the ceiling. "I wonder if //they// knew what it was. We have a large shipping industry and a whole lot of highwaymen who leech off it, but rarely would they gun down four people with automatic rifles for a single car's worth of supplies."</p> * [[“They looked like military guys.”|Crash Military]] * [[“It was just one big box. Nothing fancy.”|Crash Box]] * [[“It's a cruel world out there. Sometimes you have to gun people down with automatic rifles.”|Crash Cruel]]<p>He paused a moment. "Couldn't be. That's too brazen, even for Kells." The man shook his head, brushing the idea off entirely. "That's really not what's important right now. You have bigger things to worry about. For one thing, all you were left with was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>. There were some forms in your pocket, but they were pretty badly stained with blood."</p> <<include "Crash Process">><p>"They paid four guards to ship a single box?"</p> <p>"Not up front," you corrected him. "We were supposed to get paid upon reciept."</p> <p>"Ah. Well that explains it." He fiddles with his bun with a sudden nervous energy, as if worried about your reaction. "You didn't exactly have any money on you. Just your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>. There were some forms in your pocket, but they were pretty badly stained with blood."</p> <<include "Crash Process">><p>He snorted at this, though it wasn't exactly a friendly sort of laugh. More annoyed. "I guess you have something in common with them, huh? Well, you'll have no trouble getting work around here if that's the case." Then, he paused, his face getting serious. "Ah. And you might need to look for work. When I found you, all that was on you was your clothes and a <<for _item range $heldweapon.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("ranged")>>gun<<elseif $heldweapon.has("spiked bat")>>bat<<else>>knife<</if>><</for>>. There were some forms in your pocket, but they were pretty badly stained with blood."</p> <<include "Crash Process">> <<set $relationship.doc to $relationship.doc.fm(-20)>>\<p>It took you a moment to process that. To be fair, that //was// all you had. But it wasn't //supposed// to be all you had. Once you got here, you were supposed to deliver the cargo and get a fat paycheck. That was //supposed// to let you coast for at least a little while until you figured something out in Signal Hill. But now that paycheck was not happening.</p> <p>You tried to prop yourself up on your elbows, feeling a twinge of pain for the first time and nearly pulling that tube out of your arm in the process. "Uh... know anywhere a <<if $player.gender == "man">>guy<<elseif $player.gender == "woman">>girl<<else>>person<</if>> who's been recently shot can get some cash on short notice?"</p> <p>The doctor, after briefly panicking over your recklessness, calmed himself and contemplated the question.
