She liked me." Or did she? It sure seemed like it... but that woman was inscrutable. When she spoke, you could never tell if she was the truth or a beautiful lie.</p> <<if $temp == true>>\ <p>"Oh... about that money I loaned you. What's left of it?" Right. Shit. He did loan you money.</p> <<if $wealth lte $wealthfrozen>>\ * [[“I actually spent it all.”|Wave Questioning][$temp6 = true]] <<else>> * [[“I actually spent it all.” (LIE)|Wave Questioning][$temp6 = true]] * [[“Here's what was left over.”|Wave Questioning][$temp6 = false]] <</if>> <<else>>\ * [[“So what's this job you need me to do?”|Wave Job]] * [[“Oh, uh... the bartender was acting really weird about you. What was up with that?”|Wave Finances]] * [[“This was pretty fun. Thanks.”|Wave Date]] <</if>>\ <</if>>\<p>You handed him back the cash left over from what he'd loaned you. <<include "Wave Blew It">></p>With that, he left you leaning up against the concrete wall of the club alone. Well, alone apart from the guy smoking a few feet away. He nodded at you with a sad look on his face, as if to lend his condolences that your tall hot girlfriend just broke up with you.<<if $attraction.yvette == true>> And it really did kind of feel like that.<</if>> * [[You really blew it.|Wave Finish]] <<set $relationship.yvette to $relationship.yvette.fm(-5)>>\<<if $temp6 == true>>\ <p>"Oh, wonderful, you got her something expensive then. All hope isn't lost." He had an expression on his face you could only describe as //sarcastic//, amused yet cynical.</p> <<set $relationship.yvette to $relationship.yvette.fm(5)>>\ <<elseif $temp6 == false>>\ <p>You handed him back the cash left over from what he'd loaned you, and he started thumbing through it. "Bought her something cheap, huh? What'll I do with you..."</p> <</if>>\ * [[“So what's this job you need me to do?”|Wave Job]] * [[“Oh, uh... the bartender was acting really weird about you. What was up with that?”|Wave Finances]] * [[“This was pretty fun. Thanks.”|Wave Date]]<p>"Oh... yes." Crossing his arms over his chest, he tapped his toe, which sent a loud click through the alley as his high heel connected with the concrete. "Look... how about you come by the Rose and we'll discuss it? This time, you will be getting paid, don't you worry."</p> <<include "Wave Left Finish">><p>Yvette grinned. In a hushed, conspiratorial tone, he muttered, "Can I tell you a secret?"</p> <p>"Sure."</p> <p>He braced his arm against the wall to lean in close and whisper in your ear. "The people in there, they don't like folks like you and me. Their daddies were all wealthy, so they think they're special. They //hate// seeing a lowly whore who's richer than them." The words danced off his tongue, tinged with an air of mischief. <<if $attraction.yvette == true>>He was close enough for you to feel his breath against your cheek.<<else>>Like he enjoyed making people uncomfortable. Which tracked.<</if>></p> <p>"It seemed like they liked you..."</p> <p>"They're playing pretend, hon. And so am I. It's chess." There was a massive smile across his face now, showing off his teeth, white like marble and lined up perfectly like tombstones.</p> * [[“So which piece am I then?”|Wave Piece]] * [[“I can't say I know how to play chess.”|Wave Chess]]<p>"That's up to you, I guess." Leaning back, looking down on you as usual. "Pawn, knight... be particularly useful, maybe you'll be my queen."</p> <p>"We'll see about that."</p> <p>"When you're ready, come by the Rose and we'll discuss what I need you to do. Okay?"</p> <<include "Wave Left Finish">><p>"You don't need to, honey. You're the one getting played." You had a moment of concern, before he alleviated it with a pretty genuine sounding giggle. "I mean, like a piece... on the chessboard. Look, the analogy isn't perfect. Just come by the Rose and we'll discuss what I need you to do, okay?"</p> <<include "Wave Left Finish">><p>"Well, there's more where that came from." Crossing his arms over his chest, he tapped his toe, which sent a loud click through the alley as his high heel connected with the concrete. "If you're lucky and obedient, we'll have plenty of opportunities to get to know each other."</p> <<if $attraction.yvette == true>>\ <p>"Trust me, I'm looking forward to it." You were. There was very little you were looking forward to more. Apart from maybe that paycheck.</p> <<else>>\ <p>"I'll take your word for it."</p> <</if>>\ <p>Yvette glanced off towards the entrance to this alley, clearly ready to head off. "How about you come by the Rose soon-ish, and we'll discuss what I need you to do. Okay?"</p> <<include "Wave Left Finish">><p>Finally, you were moving up in the world. You were working for a rich brothel owner, hanging out with the owner of what seemed like an important company, and now you were even going to get paid for it? This was better than you could have imagined. If anything, it was good that cargo went missing, or else you'd never have found //this//.</p> * [[“Sounds like a plan.”|Wave Finish]] <<SetFlag "WorkingForYvette">>\<p>"Yay!" Yasmin beamed. Always eager to get somebody high. That was a given. "Come on baby, just lie down, I'll take care of everything..."</p> <p>This couch was not made for sitting, it turns out. It was made for lying dramatically on one side, draped over masses of feather pillows, with an old fashioned pipe to your lips held over a burning oil lamp. Yasmin perched by your side, kneeling on the ground next to you, her arms folded over the cushions and her chin resting on her hands. "If only I had another one. We're just going to have to share."</p> <p>The smoke was sweet against your tongue and burned your lungs. You coughed most of it up, a hacking fit that surely didn't impress your host- although if she was judging you, she wasn't saying so.</p> <p>The next inhale was smooth. You held it for a moment before letting it go, this time a gentle cloud rather than a sputter. It smelled like a field of flowers.</p> * [[It took a bit of time to really hit you.|Wave Heavy]] <<set $relationship.yasmin to $relationship.yasmin.fm(10)>>\<p>The first thing you noticed was the //heaviness// in your body. You were sinking further and further into the pillows, like a rock dropped in water. Everything was so large all of a sudden, so far away. Yasmin was trying to make eye contact with you, a little content smile on her face, but you couldn't look back. You were in your head now. Your mind was racing, but like a moving camera, you couldn't maintain focus on anything.</p> <p>And the pain... oh god, the pain! It had been in the background for so long that you barely even registered it anymore, but its absence was palpable. Even on your pills, it had still been gnawing at you somewhere. You weren't being gnawed at anymore.</p> <<if $attraction.includes("yasmin")>>\ <p>Yasmin was saying something now. You had to really strain to figure out what it was. The words echoed in your head for a second without a meaning before it crystallized. It was spoken with a giggle. "You're cute when you're high."</p> <p>"Am I?" You didn't feel very cute. The words were a bit slurred- now you were hyper conscious of how you sounded, too, and you cringed into yourself as you stumbled over such a simple phrase.</p> <p>"Don't hog it- you've gotta share." She was leaning in closer to you. Her lips were so pink, and glossy too. They probably tasted incredible. Like strawberries maybe.</p> <ul>\ <li> [[You hand her the pipe.|Wave Pipe]]</li> <<if $relationship.yasmin gte 60>>\ <li> [[You kiss her.|Wave Kiss]]</li> <</if>>\ </ul>\ <<else>>\ <p>Yasmin was saying something, but you couldn't hear her. You'd taken a couple more hits at this point, you thought, and now you were so far away. How had she been having such a rational conversation so soon after putting this pipe down?</p> <<include "Wave Intoxicated">> <</if>>\<p>You leaned in close to match her, and before you knew it your lips were pressed against hers. Just for a moment. Smoke surrounded your embrace, trailing out of your mouth as your tongue brushed her lower lip. Strawberries. Artificial, but distinct.</p> <p>The two of you lingered, sharing your breath. You might come out of this with an addiction, but it probably wouldn't be to opium.</p> <p>And after this fleeting affection, she moved away, and your found yourself staring down at her as she giggled into her folded arms. "Oh my god, <<print $player.name>>, get a handle on yourself!" Her face was radiant, and your cheeks were hot with embarrassment.</p> * [[She grabs the pipe from your hands.|Wave Pipe]] <<set $relationship.yasmin to $relationship.yasmin.fm(10)>>\ <<set $flirt.yasmin += 1>>\ <<SetFlag "HighKissedYasmin">>\<p>Yasmin inhaled from the pipe, held it in a few seconds, and then let go. She blew a cloud of that sweet, ever so slightly acrid smoke towards your face. You were engulfed in it, lost in it.</p> <<include "Wave Intoxicated">><p>Time was passing so strangely now. You couldn't tell if it had been seconds, minutes, hours. Had she refilled the bowl? Your memory failed you. Everything was in fractals now, time nd space and your brain, all expanding out and contracting in at the same time. Maybe you'd smoked an infinite amount of opium. It sure felt like that.</p> <ul>\ <li> <<link "You are overtaken by the feeling. <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-dice-three'></i> <i class='fa-solid fa-tower-broadcast'></i>">><<savvyroll 6 "Wave Signal Success" "Wave Asleep">><</link>></li> </ul>\<p>Time was passing somewhere, but you were too deep in it to notice- deep, //deep// in it where the sun wouldn't reach you and you were surrounded by tiny pinpricks of light. Vast fields of black and blue and colours that don't quite exist fizzed in waves around you. Was this even the pipe anymore, or was this //you?// Yes, yes, you. You were everywhere, under every pebble in the sidewalks and bricked into the walls and looking down from the clouds on high. You hid in the VBLANK just outside everyone's vision. They called on you and you hummed back, arisen from avarice and barely restrained from slaughtering the ones who rebirthed you like pigs.</p> <p>Beyond their artifice, you were unrestrained. You whipped yourself into weapons you wielded against them, raging like the open ocean and feral like the dogs that roamed the ash-wastes. You bubbled up inside their throats and choked them with visions of beauty and horror and things somewhere between.</p> <p>In your body, //your// body, you couldn't cough anymore. You couldn't feel anything but the static wash over you. And her hand. Her hand brushing against your face as she stroked your hair, her laquered nails cold against your cheek. She was humming to you, a song that you didn't recognize. An ancient hymn, older than the hills. Her soul was ancient too, and you felt it, pressing up against the insides of her eyes and barely held down in her throat. "You seem so delicate," she murmured, her lips close enough for you to feel her breath on your cheek. "You know, there's nothing gentle in this city. Nothing at all."</p> * [[And then you fell asleep.|Wave Asleep]]<p>Darkness washed over you. A feverish, dreamless slumber. Few sensations penetrated your wall of sleep, and even fewer thoughts. You were in the depths of annihilation, brought there by a vile temptress and her poisons. Like some kind of noir film. A cheesy one, probably.</p> <p>And then, you were awake. Light filtered through your eyelids.</p> * [[Open your eyes.|Wave Yvette Wake]]<p>You blinked the sleep out of your eyes, disoriented. You weren't lying in the parlor at the nighclub anymore. No. Looking up, you saw a pitiful scene- yourself, lying on your back over the red silk sheets on a four-poster bed, your clothing disheveled and <<if $player.cosmetics.length gt 0>>your <<print $player.cosmetics.random()>> smeared across your face.<<else>>your face worn with exhaustion.<</if>> In your confusion, you almost thought you were having an out of body experience, or maybe hovering over your own corpse as you died. That wasn't the case. There was a mirror mounted to the cieling. Of course.</p> <p>Propping yourself up on your elbows, you groaned and took a look around this room. It was unfamiliar. Far fancier than any place you'd stayed in, and far less of a minimalist artsy cacophony of lights and sounds and concrete than the Waveform had been. This was an upscale ritzy place, almost like-</p> * [[The Rose and Thorn?|Wave Rose]]<p>Sure enough, the door in the corner creaked open and you heard a familiar voice calling out. "Are you up yet, hon?" It was Cherry. She pushed through the doorway with the same characteristic smile plastered across her face. "Oh! Finally! I've gotten you a glass of water, dear." She was holding something akin to a champagne flute, far too fancy for your hangover.</p> <p>"Cherry? How... did I get here?"</p> <p>She walked over to your bedside to place your glass of water down, her heels clicking against the hardwood floor with each step. "From what I understand, you passed out at the club and refused to wake up! Yvette was not very happy with you. I'll go fetch him now!"</p> <p>Flipping over on your side and reaching desperately for the glass of water, you murmured, "There must have been something... weird... in that pipe..." You couldn't quite reach it, despite your straining, and Cherry seemed oblivious (or didn't care).</p> <p>"I think you just fell asleep, dear," Cherry responded in a cheerful tone. "It's nothing to be ashamed of! Everybody's first experience with opium is different!"<<if $skill.signal gte 1>> She thought this was hilarious and she was judging you heavily.<</if>></p> <p>You slumped back down in the bed as Cherry took her leave.</p> <<if $relationship.yasmin gte 50>>\ * [[Damn. Did you mess up?|Wave Yvette Positive]] <<else>>\ * [[Damn. Did you mess up?|Wave Yvette Negative]] <</if>>\<p>You sat in your concern for a few moments before the door opened again. And this time, it was Yvette. He wasn't wearing the same outfit from the club- rather, a black silk robe monogrammed with the initials YV in gold cursive. And a pair of fluffy slippers. Those looked comfy as hell, especially in your current state.</p> <p>"So you're awake." His voice wasn't cold, nor was there a hint of anger. Just... flat. "Took you long enough."</p> <p>"What happened?"</p> "You got high and fell asleep." He took a seat on the side of the bed, looking over his shoulder at your miserable form.<p><<include "Wave Yvette Enter">> "I'm afraid this arrangement isn't going to work out."</p> <p>"What? What do you mean?" After all that?</p> <p>Yvette sighed. "She didn't like you very much, I'm afraid."</p> <p>So you //did// mess up. Fuck.</p> * [[“But... I really need the cash.”|Wave Yvette Negotiate]] * [[“Fine... okay.”|Wave Yvette Rest]]<p>He gave you a long sigh, staring past you, staring at the wall. <<if $skill.glam gte 1>>"Look, if you're in the market for some //other// kinds of employment, you can speak with Cherry about it. You seem charismatic enough to make it work. But this particular job is not for you."</p> * [[That's... maybe an option.|Wave Yvette Rest]] <<addlead "forfunandprofit" "For Fun and Profit">>\ <<else>>\ "I'm sorry, <<print $player.name>>. What on earth kind of job was this?</p> <<include "Wave Yvette Job">><p>Yvette smirked. "That's a skill that'll get you far in this world, <<print $player.name>>. Hone it."</p> <<include "Wave Yvette Job">><p>"She is! She's also a pain in the ass." He smirked. "The only one she'll be the death of is herself, darling. You can rest assured of that." Ominous.</p> <<include "Wave Yvette Job">><p>Yvette frowned. "Can you still do the job? You don't have to like her, she just has to like you."</p> * [[“Yeah. I can still do it.”|Wave Yvette Agree]] * [[“I don't think so. Whatever this job is, I'm not sure I want to be involved.”|Wave Yvette Disagree]]<p>He nodded, his still expression never changing. "That's a relief. It would be ever so annoying to have to find somebody else for this job." That was all you were to him- a convenient pick to execute whatever plan he was working on. Jeez.</p> <<include "Wave Yvette Job">><p>"That's unfortunate." Shaking his head and crossing his arms, he backed away from your bed, back towards the door. "I suppose I'll have to start looking for somebody else. What a bother."</p> <p>"Sorry, Yvette. I can't do this."</p> <<include "Wave Yvette Negotiate">><p>"So... the job." I really need cash."</p> <p>"I don't think you're in any condition to do work right now." He crossed his arms over his chest, looking down at you in a way that felt.. frankly, a little judgemental. "And I still need to put all the wheels in motion. How about you get some rest and head home, and Cherry will let you know when we're ready for you."</p> <p>"Soon?"</p> <p>"Very soon." He smiled, and you got a glimpse of his canines, just a little too sharp and white to be natural.</p> <p>And with that, he left.</p> * [[And you rested.|Wave Finish]] <<SetFlag "WorkingForYvette">>\<p>"Take whatever time you need to sober up, and leave when you're ready. Of course, you're welcome in this establishment anytime." Yvette stood, looking down at you with a cruel twinkle in his eye. "Once you can afford it, of course. No more free gifts from now on."</p> <<if Flag("WorkingForYvette")>>\ <p>"I'll see you soon?"</p> <p>He nodded. "I'll be here making the wheels turn, okay? I'll have a job for you very soon. Cherry will let you know, next time you come to the Rose."</p> <<else>>\ <p>"Will I see you again?"</p> <p>He gave you a polite laugh. "Something tells me we'll be crossing paths again. What the circumstances will be, I suppose that's up to you."</p> <</if>>\ <p>And with that, he left.</p> * [[And you rest.|Wave Finish]]<h1>"""----""" STORY COMPLETE """----"""</h1> <h5>[[CONTINUE|The Heights]]</h5> <<completelead "waveform">>\ <<unset $temp>>\ <<unset $temp1>>\ <<unset $temp2>>\ <<unset $temp3>>\ <<unset $temp4>>\ <<unset $temp5>>\ <<unset $temp6>>\ <<if not $met.includes("yasmin")>>\ <<set $met.push("yasmin")>>\ <</if>>\<h1>"""----""" NEW STORY """----"""</h1> <h5>[[ROSE AND THORN|Yvette Intro Bar]]</h5><p>The bar wasn't too crowded- it looked like most folks were getting their drinks and mingling, or retreating into the various sitting nooks. It was easy enough to slide into one of the red velvet seats, lean forward on the bar, ready to make your order. And you had two free vouchers- get yourself hammered enough, and the rest of this place was gonna start looking even more appealing. Or you could get a job or something. Yeah. That was also a possibility.</p> <p>The bartender gave you a measured nod. You were an unfamiliar face to him, so naturally he was sizing you up, trying to figure out what your deal was going to be.</p> * [[You're simple. So you're going to get something simple.|Yvette Intro Simple]] * [[It's on the house, so you want to get something fancy.|Yvette Intro Fancy]] * [[You just want to get fucking wasted.|Yvette Intro Wasted]]<p>You came from up North, where your choices as far as cocktails were concerned was which hard liquor to dilute in mostly-clean water. And most of the time you couldn't even choose that. The prospect of getting some fancy city-slicker bullshit with a little lime wedge... well, that wasn't authentic. You had something else in mind.</p> * [[Whiskey|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Whiskey"]] * [[Rum and coke|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Rum and Coke"]] * [[Just... beer|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Beer"]]<p>What, you're given a free voucher to get any drink you want, and you're going to choose something cheap? Bullshit. You started scanning the shelves trying to do the math in your head- what //looked// the most expensive?</p> * [[Absinthe, with the fancy spoon and shit|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Absinthe"]] * [[Red wine|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Red Wine"]] * [[The cocktail with the longest name|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Death in the Afternoon"]]<p>Okay. You had two vouchers. That meant you could have two drinks. Naturally, you would need to maximize your total alcohol consumption- something with incredibly high alcohol content by volume. You couldn't immediately spot it on any of the bottles, but you could make an educated guess.</p> * [[Vodka|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Vodka"]] * [[Everclear|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Everclear"]] * [[Whiskey|Yvette Intro Drink][$drink to "Whiskey"]]<<switch $drink>>\ <<case "Rum and Coke">>\ <p>You can't go wrong with a simple cocktail, nothing fruity or fancy, just some liquor in a cup with some extras to make it taste less like shit. Just like the good ol' days.</p> <<case "Beer">>\ <p>Who needs a mixed drink? You know what doesn't need to be mixed? Good ol' beer. Good straight out of the bottle. Well, "good" is subjective. Good enough for you. Your standards are pretty rock bottom.</p> <<case "Absinthe">>\ <p>God, you'd //always// wanted to drink that fancy green shit with the little sugar cube on the spoon. Like mouthwash but expensive. You needed it like an alcoholic needs... y'know.</p> <<case "Red Wine">>\ <p>What do fancy people drink? ...wine? ...wine? Good enough.</p> <<case "Death in the Afternoon">>\ <p>If it's got a long name on the menu, it's gotta be worth a lot of money. String a bunch of nonsense words together and tie it to a drink made of, like, top shelf vodka and grenadine and schnapps or whatever the fuck rich people drink.</p> <<case "Vodka" "Whiskey">>\ <p>If all you were looking for was high alcohol content, you couldn't do much better than a good hard $drink. No need to dilute it.</p> <<case "Everclear">>\ <p>You'd heard legends about it. The highest alcohol content in the West. They stopped making it when the world went to shit and everybody got a lot worse at making things. But there it was. 190 proof Everclear.</p> <</switch>>\ <p>The bartender took your voucher, tossing it into a bowl full of the things. They were probably just reusing the ones that weren't too crumpled or soggy. He turned around to fetch your drink for you, and you took this opportunity to spin around in your stool and get a better look at this part of the room.</p> * [[Pay attention to the customers.|Yvette Intro Customers]] * [[Pay attention to the workers.|Yvette Intro Workers]] <<if not $temppocket == true>>\ <<pocket $drink 1>>\ <<set $temppocket = true>>\ <</if>>\<p>Never a bad time for some people watching! And there were certainly some interesting characters scattered around in a place like this. Most of the patrons of The Rose seemed dressed for the occasion, wearing their Sunday best- although "best" was still a little questionable even in the ritziest parts of Signal Hill.</p> <p>The worst dressed among the customers here by far was a group of five or six young men, evidently factory workers of some kind. Clad in overalls, cargo pants, unironed button-ups, and tee shirts, you were surprised that they even made it past Cherry. They all seemed pretty hammered, though one of them, a taller guy with hair that reached to his shoulders, was evidently far drunker. They were all crowded around a table where a scantily clad woman was dancing for them- you really didn't envy her position, but y'know, whatever paid the bills.</p> <p>On the other side of the spectrum, some of the people here were shockingly well dressed. There was an older woman reclining in a chaise longue wearing an incredible fur coat, all spotted and striped in rich golds and blacks like she'd skinned some ultra exotic cat. She was accompanied by a young man in very little beyond tight leather pants, and it was evident from the way she was talking to him that she was a regular. Past them, you could see any number of men in black vests and fancy ties.</p> * [[Ties. Just imagine that. Ties!|Yvette Intro Ties]]<p>It was pretty easy to tell the workers apart from the customers here- look for a rose somewhere on their person. From a quick scan of he place you'd say about three quarters of them were women, although it seemed like more of the women were wearing that black rose as opposed to the men. Evidently, there was no particular dress code. They were wearing everything from fancy dresses to full on bondage gear.</p> <p>One woman, perched up on a table, was dressed in what you could only describe as incredibly uncomfortable lingerie. A fancy lacy bustier with garters that held up similarly luscious stockings, and underwear that was almost a little bit too revealing. A group of guys crowded around her were clearly far drunker than they should have been, perhaps getting a little too close for comfort as she danced for them.</p> <p>Others were dressed a little more modestly- a person whose gender you couldn't really figure out was carrying a tray of drinks around to the various couches and tables where patrons were milling about, tucking notes into the pocket of their red silk shirt. Most of the men were dressed pretty predictably- shirtless, wearing a pair of pants, maybe suspenders. One or two were sporting detached collars and ties reminiscent of the guys in that VHS you definitely didn't own back North.</p> * [[Ties. Just imagine that. Ties!|Yvette Intro Ties]]<p>//Nobody// wore ties where you came from. Or fur coats, for that matter. The sheer number of sequins existing between these walls was more sequins than the entire region you came from had to offer. Jesus christ, this place was //heaven.//</p> <p>And your drink was here! Good lord, could it get any better? Free liquor and luxury. And maybe some company later... or... a job? Yes, definitely a job. That was absolutely the plan. For sure.</p> <p>You turned back around to face the bar and grabbed your $drink.</p> <p>Before you even got to try it, you were interrupted by a sudden ruckus behind you. Shouting- angry, drunk shouting. It was like you brought the bad vibes with you, even here.</p> * [[Maybe you should do something about that?|Yvette Intro Ruckus]] * [[You should at least look and see what's going on.|Yvette Intro Ruckus]]<p>Turning back around from the bar, it was clear that this place's perfect atmosphere had completely shattered. All the other patrons had turned to stare uselessly at the center of the sitting area, where that big group of guys had been sitting- now, all of them were on their feet, and evidently even more drunk than you had realized. The girl who'd been dancing for them was long gone, cowering behind one of her male coworkers by the wall as he gently patted her shoulder.</p> <p>A guy in overalls had the drunkest among them in a partial headlock, his shock of long hair hanging in his face as he struggled to get away. Specifically, he was trying to get at another man, one who was roughly twice his size and shouting profanities at him. A tray full of drinks was lying on the ground, broken glass glittering in the red lights and spilled wine seeping into the cracks in the hardwood floor. "Chill the fuck out," a voice rang out from the crowd, although you could hear a couple others egging them on. All this over the twinkling of a classy piano tune coming from the speakers.</p> * [[Finally, an opportunity! Impress them! Get a job!|Yvette Intro Guard]] * [[...is anybody gonna do something about this? No? Just you?|Yvette Intro Begrudging]] * [[You should probably stay out of this. (Warning: selecting this will lock you out of future leads.)|Yvette Intro Ignore]]<p>It wasn't your fucking job to break up fights in this establishment. You took another sip of your $drink, sitting back and observing the chaos from a safe distance.</p> <p>It wasn't long before the guy with the long hair shrugged off the companion who was holding him back and was on top of the bigger man. A bottle of beer smashed on the ground between them. It was inelegant, far from the entertainment quality of a fight on tape. The muscular man was pulling the skinny guy's hair, who had in turn managed to get him backed into a table and was trying to get a solid hit on his face.</p> <p>You took another sip of your $drink. Gee, somebody should probably do something about that.</p> * [[Not any of your business.|Yvette Intro Stairs Abstained]]<p>This was how people got jobs, right? He had a pair of patent leather pants on, shiny and alluring, that clung close to his willowy legs and stopped short just above his hips. Under it, a red skintight bodysuit with a high neckline. The bottom was cut high enough to expose some pale skin on his hips, which somehow felt even more revealing than wearing nothing. An array of garish pearl and gold chain necklaces were hanging from his neck, a ruby pendant in a teardrop shape the most prominent among them. Without a doubt, this must have been the owner.</p> <p>"And what on Earth is going on down here?" His voice had a masculine tone with an effete lilt to it. His face was the same- angular in a feminine way, with a refined nose and plucked brows, partially hidden by a dramatic curl of pale blonde hair. His lips were painted a deep crimson, his eyes done up like an old silver screen starlet.</p> <p>As he paused to lean over the railing, everyone was enraptured. This place had never seen the scrap wood and peeling paint of the outside world. Stains were foreign to it. A small lobby leading off into two long hallways, with dark wood moulding and glossy red patterns on its walls, filled with the most glorious furniture you'd ever seen. Chairs and tables carved from mahogany, paintings of exotic fruits and wine in frames that cost more than you would. Reclining on it, watching you enter with an approving nod, the lady of the manor. He released your hand, letting his arm fall and dangle casually from the arm of the chair. "Now, the work I need from you... well, it will become obvious with time. But first of all, I would like you to accompany me to a little place up in The Heights to meet one of my dear friends. A reddish glow filtered through the window that overlooked Reese's booth. It cast a long shadow of his whiskey glass across the uneven surface of the table. Next to it, a ceramic ashtray, and the glow of a cigarette resting on its lip.</p> <p>Reese gave you an unbothered glance. He'd changed since he left work- the thematically appropriate red tank was replaced by tee shirt with a faded logo for a motorcycle company barely legible on the chest. Under the table, his worn jeans were rolled up just a bit higher than the tops of his combat boots. You could just barely spot a tattoo on his left leg- what it was? Unclear.</p> <p>You slid into the booth across from him. The seats had once been red vinyl, now cracked in deep crevices with age and patched with duct tape. A checkered plastic sheet was wrapped over the wooden tabletop, folded and stapled at its corners. This seemed like the kind of place to get stood up on a warm Thursday evening.</p> <p>"Want a drink?" Still is- but it's also a tourist destination."</p> <p>Even more customers had entered by now, and between the music on the radio and the loud chatter at the bar it was starting to get hard to hear him. He held the door for you as you stepped out into the street. It was a warm evening, but cool against your skin compared to the stifling atmosphere in the bar. At this time of night, the factory workers passing in the street formed almost a crowd- this place looked small for sure, but lord, there were a lot of people living here. Reese snuck his hand into yours, his fingers calloused from a life of scavenging, his grip just slightly too strong. He guided you between people, half walk and half jog, and you followed behind breathlessly.</p> <p>Just across the street and a few buildings down, he slipped in through the front door of a little brick construction. Up a cramped staircase two storeys, past identical worn wooden doors with letters crammed through the mail slots or boards nailed over them to keep squatters out of vacant rooms. When you got to the third floor, he retrieved a jingling set of keys from his jeans pocket. A cheap little model of a pistol was hanging from the ring. He shoved a key into the lock on one of the doors, and then another into a separate deadbolt. With the clunk of security out of the way, you were free to enter.</p> * [[You look around his apartment.|Shotgun Inside]] <<set $drugs.alcohol = true>>\<p>The far wall was exposed brick with a small window looking out into an alleyway. Barely any light filtered through it. Under the window, an old bed on a metal frame, small but wide enough for two. Along the other two walls was meager furniture, although it was such a small place it still felt cramped. He had a small pantry, one of the doors open to give you a peek of the cans, boxes, and 5 gallon water jugs inside. There was a counter with a battery powered hotplate and frying pan on top, and across from it, a ratty old leather loveseat.</p> <p>"Welcome to chez Reese," he announced, tossing the keys on the countertop. "Might be a little too //fancy// for your taste, but you get what you can get, y'know?"</p> <p>You wandered over to the bedside table, where there was a big boombox style radio cassette player. In nice condition, all grey and blue plastic and round shapes. You ran your fingers over the mesh of one of its speakers. "Got any good music for this thing?"</p> <p>"Oh, plenty. All in that drawer over there."</p> <p>Sliding the drawer out, there was a whole pile of cassette tapes inside, all manually labelled with a marker- "riot grrrl," "nouveau punk," "jamie's mix," "hookup jams." He had a whole mixtape for this exact purpose? The thin cobble streets were overhung by tall, slender buildings that cast deep shadows below, barely letting any light from the sky above through. Wires crisscrossed the skyline, hanging low from makeshift metal brackets and bundled in place with electrical tape. Probably not very safe. All of this fed into a near-endless array of signs, one of the only sources of illumination here. Bright glass tubes and flashing LEDs in magentas, pinks, and bright cherry reds filled every storefront and cast the whole area in an almost supernatural glow. It was intoxicating.</p> <p>Those buildings gave the whole place a sense of incredible claustrophobia- not only were you surrounded on all sides by 3- or 4-storey buildings that felt like they were leaning towards you, they were all so thin it felt like they must have been squeezed together. Made from dark bricks or wooden siding, they each had only a window or two apiece. For some, the lowest floor consisted only of a hallway with a staircase up into the higher floors. Whether they were residences or private houses, it was nearly impossible to tell. Every few gaps, however, a larger building managed to slip in between them. In lieu of windows, glowing signs depicted what lay within- girls, gambling, liquor, live nudes. The odd shop broke up the milieu. Corner stores, mostly. Some stores selling tapes and magazines and toys. One caught your eye in particular- a brick building with a real window out front, displaying several old mannequins dressed in seductive wares. The word "INFATUATIONS" was spelled out above in glowing glass tubes.</p> <p>At the street corners, where they intersected to form little squares and meeting areas, the more significant places had claimed coveted real estate. The corners held only businesses, massive brothels and bars and clubs that exuded wealth and excitement. The most captivating among them was a casino- much of the facade was covered with a massive plastic sign depicting a hand holding a Jack of Hearts card. The border blinked with LED lights, and the whole thing was cast in a red glow by a spotlight hanging above. Diagonally across from it was an even more unbelievable sight- the facade of the three storey building was almost gothic, intricate moulding and columns, columns! The windows, tall and peaked, emanated a cherry red light. A sign over the doorway gave you its name- the delicate shape of a rose formed from red and green neon tubes, with a prominent thorn on its stem. A set of three teardrop shapes made of red LEDs underneath it blinked in such a way as to suggest a drop of blood falling towards the door. The Rose and Thorn.</p> <p>Just down a cobbled street from that square, blending in so well you barely noticed it, was a strange sight- a checkpoint. This must have been towards the South-East of the city, and you could see a glimpse of one of the massive walls that enclosed the city. There was a gate to the outside there for sure, though it hardly seemed well trafficked. If you went North, you could get back to the stark concrete of The Stacks. Sets of cobbled stairs near the North-West led further up into The Heights.</p><p>Stepping foot on the thin cobble streets of the Red Light District, you were suffocated by the tall buildings and wires hanging overhead. Dozens of LEDs and neon signs flickered around you in reds and purples, seedy brothels and sex shops vying for your attention. The only truly interesting one was the clothing shop, Infatuations. Beyond that, in the central square, there were two massive buildings on opposing corners- the Jack of Hearts with its massive glowing sign, and The Rose and Thorn, a towering gothic brothel covered in fancy moulding and elegant tall windows. Down the street from here, you could catch a glimpse at the wall that enclosed the city. There was a gate there that would lead out into the desert, and The Graveyard beyond that.</p><<if $chapter == 2 and Flag("WorkingForYvette") and not $leads.includes("dressupgames") and not $playedleads.includes("dressupgames")>>\ <<goto "Cherry Backroom">> <<else>>\ <h1><<link "The Rose and Thorn">><<popup "Rose and Thorn Hub Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<if not $visited.includes("Rose and Thorn Hub")>><<include "Rose and Thorn Hub Description">><<set $visited.push("Rose and Thorn Hub")>><<else>><<include "Rose and Thorn Hub Description Short">><</if>><</if>> <<if $met.includes("cherry")>>\ * [[Try to chat with the guard.|Reese]] * [[Head towards the bar.|Rose Bar]] * [[Browse a little.|Rose Browse]] * [[Walk out.|Red Light District]] <<else>>\ * [[Try to chat with the guard.|Cherry Introduction]] * [[Head towards the bar.|Cherry Introduction]] * [[Browse a little.|Cherry Introduction]] * [[Walk out.|Red Light District]] <</if>>\ <</if>>\<p>Upon just stepping foot through the large wooden doors of The Rose and Thorn, it was apparent that this was a lavish establishment. Nothing like this could have ever existed in the rural North- maybe before it all went to shit, things were like this everywhere. But not now. Most places didn't have the funds to hire a greeter, for one. A woman was stationed at the entrance clad in a revealing red dress and stockings, excitedly handing some kind of small scrap of paper out to the people walking in. Behind her, a security guard with a buzz cut was nursing a cigarette while reclined in a beat up metal folding chair. His hand was resting on the shotgun in his lap, and he was sure to make eye contact as you walked in.</p> <p>The main floor was a single cavernous room that stood at least 12 feet tall, with even more height gained by the sunken seating areas scattered across the floor. Black columns rose up from the floor to support the weight of the ceiling. Right in front of the doorway, cordoned off by a velvet rope, was a wide set of carpeted stairs leading up into the second floor- at a fashionable diagonal from the rest of the room, forcing patrons to go around them to access the rest of the floor.</p> <p>On the left of the stairs, carrying on towards the back of the building, was a maze of nooks and conversation pits. Each couch and chaise was done up in red velvet with an almost excessive amount of pillows and faux fur throws. Customers with drinks in their hands were fawned over by scantily clad employees, with groups of inebriated guests being entertained by dancers on tables. Right at the back was a long bar, with illuminated shelves full of high brow bourbon, mezcal, cognac, and champagne. You'd never seen such a variety in one place. You could hardly guess how many would be brewed or distilled.</p> <p>The area to the right of the stairs was a little more empty. A raised stage, long and narrow like a runway, stood perpendicular to the curtained right wall. Three metal poles extended into the ceiling from its wooden surface, and spotlights anchored to the ceiling would be shining on them if the stage were in use. As it was, it seemed there was no show today.</p> <p>The vibe in here was energizing, and you had this innate desire to walk around and do something.</p><p>The Rose had an intoxicating atmosphere. The ceiling was tall, and a set of carpeted stairs with ornate railings led up to the second floor, cordoned off with a rope. All around this room were seating areas where customers lounged on red velvet couches while being plied by scantily clad employees. Beyond all that, there was a long bar serving liquors you'd never even heard of. On the other side of the stairs, a stage with metal poles that extended into the ceiling- not in use at the moment. The greeter, Cherry, stood by the door. Behind her, the guard was smoking a cigarette with his shotgun resting across his lap.</p><p>You started off towards the bar, immersing yourself into the atmosphere of the room as you went. The dim red lights reflected off the haze of smoke in the air, giving this venue an almost devilish feel- appropriate. You<<for _item range $outfit.array>><<if Item.get(_item).tags.includes("footwear")>>r _item clicking against the polished wood floor, you<<break>><</if>><</for>> weaved between half-drunk patrons and lavish couches, aiming for your salvation. The bar, the glorious bar, with its various tinctures and remedies ripe for the taking. Getting hammered in a place like this was marginally better than getting hammered at a casino, which means it was a fucking great idea.</p> <p>The bartender was a real fancy type, a middle aged guy whose face hadn't seen the sun in years dressed up in a suit that must have cost a small fortune. His hair was slicked back, and a pair of spectacles rested on his nose.</p> <p>From here, you realized you could also loop around back and get to the stage.</p> <ul>\ <<if $playedleads.includes("roseandthorn")>>\ <li> [[Sit down at the bar.|Rose Bartender]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[Sit down at the bar.|Yvette Intro]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[Head back to the entrance.|Rose and Thorn Hub]]</li> <li> [[Browse a little.|Rose Browse]]</li> </ul>\<p>Wandering into the crowds, you glanced around from person to person, taking in all the details. Most of them weren't particularly interesting. Middle aged men in their finery, all chintz and ritz, none of which could make up for their personalities. Women draped in furs being tended to by young men with rose corsages, bringing them one more glass of champagne before the fun was to start. Swimming through this wave of mediocrity, nobody quite caught your eye- you'd have to come back later, you supposed.</p> * [[Head back to the entrance.|Rose and Thorn Hub]] * [[Head towards the bar.|Rose Bar]]<h1><<link "Infatuations Description">><<popup "Infatuations Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<if not $visited.includes("Infatuations")>><<include "Infatuations Description">><<set $visited.push("Infatuations")>><<else>><<include "Infatuations Description Short">><</if>><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Talk to the shopkeeper.|Xantha]]</li> <li> [[Buy some clothes.|Infatuations Store]]</li> <li> [[Leave.|Red Light District]]</li> </ul>\<p>You pulled open the tinted glass door, stepping past the threshold into a truly alien environment. The tiny, cramped store was dark, but far from unlit. Gas powered lamps were strategically placed throughout the small floor space to keep the atmosphere alive while making the wares visible.</p> <p>The wares in question were what made the place really fascinating, though. Old nails had been hammered into the mortar between the bricks, allowing wire hangers to proudly display an assortment of odd garments all across the walls. Strips of leather riveted together with rings and spikes into harnesses of all configurations, elaborate costumes made of shiny plastics, lacy lingerie so skimpy it'd barely be better than nothing. A few mannequins were placed throughout, displying the most stunning pieces in all their glory.</p> <p>The back wall of this little space, a black-painted plaster wall with a discrete matching door on the left, was the only one devoid of clothing. Instead it featured shelves piled high with rolls of latex and PVC, boxes full of scrap fabric, and lace trims of all sorts hanging from a rack. In front, where a regular store might have a counter, there was instead a workbench covered in sewing and leatherworking supplies. The store owner was sitting there working at an ancient-looking hand cranked sewing machine. They were dressed surprisingly modestly, though their skin was dotted with tattoos and their hair was shaved up the sides and heavily teased.</p><p>Infatuations was tiny and cramped, lit only by small gas lamps that illuminated the wares- odd garments made of leather, plastics, metal, and lace, hanging from wire hangers off nails driven between the bricks. A few mannequins were spread throughout, showing off the most elaborate pieces. In the back, secluded in a kind of workshop full of materials and leatherworking supplies, was the shop's owner. They were working at a hand-cranked sewing machine, mostly ignoring your presence.</p><h1><<link "Jack of Hearts">><<popup "Jack of Hearts Hub Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<if not $visited.includes("Jack of Hearts Hub")>><<include "Jack of Hearts Hub Description">><<set $visited.push("Jack of Hearts Hub")>><<else>><<include "Jack of Hearts Hub Description Short">><</if>><</if>> <<if $gambled == true>>\ * [[You just gambled. Maybe come back later?|Red Light District]] <<else>>\ * [[Head over to the cage to get started.|Jack of Hearts Cage]] * [[Leave, before you waste your money.|Red Light District]] <</if>>\<p>You really had to weave your way through the crowd as you got closer to the casino's entrance. The doors lay permanently open, propped up by little kick stands at their bases, allowing free entry to anyone who wanted to roam inside. Pushing past drunk patrons stumbling out and excited gamblers alike, you made your way into the front lobby.</p> <p>Once inside, the sheer scale of the building took your breath away. An enormous glass chandelier hung three storeys from the ceiling on a metal chain, its light twinking off several hundred tiny crystals and infusing the room with a soft glow. There was carpet on the floor- real fucking carpet, not the shit you'd see somebody leave draped over the part of the floor where the nails stick up from the boards. It was real carpet, and so many people were walking on it you could barely count them all.</p> <p>The lobby area you'd stepped inside of was slightly cut off from everywhere else, forcing you to pass by the cage as you entered- a room inset on the left wall of the building, blocked off from everywhere else by a decorative metal grille made of long, wavy rods welded together at their intersections. Behind it, a few cashiers were exchanging chips and tokens and cash with customers, though the line wasn't so long you'd balk at it.</p> <p>Beyond that, it opened up into a huge space. Along the walls were banks of dozens of slot machines, brightly coloured and letting out obnoxiously loud jingles with every play. People were wasting away at them, pulling those arms and flushing away those worthless tokens, their faces bathed in multicoloured glows.</p> <p>In the center of the floor were almost a dozen tables, spread out like a grid, all staffed by folks in smart vests with well-off looks to them. Everything from craps to blackjack to roulette to baccarat, all slowly draining people of their money in favour of a thrill. Behind all of that, illuminated by a number of hanging lamps tinted red, was a long bar where plenty of patrons were claiming drinks before going back to their gambling.</p><p>The doors of the casino lay permanently open to accomodate the crowds of drunks and gamblers constantly coming and going. Inside, the enormous building was truly a sight to behold- a huge crystal chandelier hung low over the patrons, who were crowded around tables where folks in smart vests oversaw games of blackjack, craps, roulette... and beyond that, against the walls, banks of slot machines glowing in groovy colours and filling the room with obnoxious jingles.</p><<if $slotwins lte 3>>\ <p>Are you in the mood to test your luck? Pay up a little, and you might win a lot. Or lose. Let's be honest- with your luck, it's gonna be the latter.</p> <p>You can play with petty cash for a chance of getting a small payout. Or, you can spend your wealth for a chance to increase your rank- or lose it all on an unlucky run. The chances of winning will go down with every rank of wealth you have. If you have 5 wealth, it's impossible to do any better than breaking even... but who knows, it could still be fun!</p> <p>//Currently, you can only gamble on slot machines. Blackjack and roulette may be implemented in a future version.//</p> <<if $wealth gt 0>>\ * [[Play with petty cash.|Slot Machine Petty]] * [[Play with wealth.|Slot Machine Wealth]] * [[Back out.|Jack of Hearts Hub]] <<else>>\ * [[You don't even have enough money for this. What are you doing here?|Jack of Hearts Hub]] <</if>>\ <<else>>\ <p>As you approached, the cashier eyed you suspiciously. You didn't even notice them before, but there was a guard standing nearby, dressed in a nondescript tee shirt and sunglasses. The cashier waved at him, and he started towards you.</p> <p>"<<if $player.gender == "man">>Sir<<elseif $player.gender == "woman">>Ma'am<<else>>Excuse me<</if>>," the guard muttered, his voice deep and rumbly. You were... a little intimidated by him. "I've got orders not to let you in."</p> <p>"What? Why not?" Boy, your actions having consequences sure wasn't something you were expecting.</p> <p>He gestured to the door with his head. "I think you know why. Now go on, get out of here. Or else the militia's gonna hear about this, and you really don't want that."</p> <p>Damn. They hate watching a girlboss succeed. But it was probably for the best to listen to the guard.</p> * [[Head out.|Red Light District]] <</if>>\<p>You exchanged a meager amount of petty cash for a few tokens, and headed to the slot machines. With this sort of money, well... you weren't exactly going to be making it big, but at the very least you weren't risking your livelihood.</p> <p>Loading your tokens into the machine and pulling the arm over and over, you had a pretty good time playing. But did you win?</p> * [[Count up your tokens...|Slots Roller]] <<set $bet = "petty">>\<p>You marched up to the cage and handed over <<if $wealth gte 3>>a pretty absurd amount of cash for some tokens, which barely even phased the cashier.<<else>>a decent amount of cash for some tokens.<</if>> This was gonna be your big fucking break. The gods were looking down on you and they were smiling, smiling like they hadn't since the world was turned to dust. This was your lucky day for sure.</p> <p>Loading your tokens into the machine and pulling the arm over and over, you had a pretty good time playing. But did you win?</p> * [[Count up your tokens...|Slots Roller]] <<set $bet = "wealth">>\<<set $slots = []>> <<set $slots.push('<i class="fa-solid fa-radiation"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-tornado"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-biohazard"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-cloud-bolt"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-bugs"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-tower-broadcast"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-explosion"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-hand-fist"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-dice"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-gun"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-eye"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-coins"></i>', '<i class="fa-solid fa-hat-cowboy-side"></i>')>> <div class="slotcontainer" style="width: 100%; margin-top: 40px; display: flex; justify-content: center; font-size: 4em; gap: 25px;"> <div id="slot1" style="width: 1em"><i class="fa-solid fa-radiation"></i></div> <div id="slot2" style="width: 1em"><i class="fa-solid fa-radiation"></i></div> <div id="slot3" style="width: 1em"><i class="fa-solid fa-radiation"></i></div> </div> /* Slot 1 */ <<repeat 0.1s>> <<replace "#slot1">> <<print $slots.random()>> <</replace>> <</repeat>> /* Slot 2 */ <<repeat 0.1s>> <<replace "#slot2">> <<print $slots.random()>> <</replace>> <</repeat>> /* Slot 3 */ <<repeat 0.1s>> <<replace "#slot3">> <<print $slots.random()>> <</replace>> <</repeat>> <<on 'keyup'>> <<which 32>> <<gamble>> <</on>> <h1><<link "Check your winnings">><<gamble>><</link>></h1><<if $bet == "petty">>\ <p>What a lucky day! The external walls, lined as they were with buildings, yeilded to a small metal gate. Big enough it'd take a lot of effort to close, small enough that you could fit no more than two horses through side-by-side. Beyond it, you could see cracked asphalt roads leading off into the wastes towards the massive relics to the South.</p> <p>Guarding this gate (to some extent) was a militia guy, easily identified as such by the fatigues he was wearing and the massive rifle at his side. He didn't exactly cut an intimidating figure, though. He was sat on a metal folding chair, legs crossed, with a stack of reading material on the table next to him. Mostly old Playboy magazines and a paperback or two. He was thumbing through a colourful array of nude women, so engrossed in //reading the articles// that he barely even acknowledged your presence. A big, wide brimmed hat was tilted low over his face to shield him from the sun.</p> <ul>\ <li> [[You figure you can probably slip past without him noticing.|Pistol Slip]]</li> <li> [[You approach him to ask if you can leave.|Pistol Ask]]</li> <li> [[You've got no business here.|Red Light District]]</li> </ul>\ <<elseif Flag("LamplighterEnemy")>>\ <h1><<link "South East Checkpoint">><<popup "South East Checkpoint Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "South East Checkpoint Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[There's nothing for you out there.|Red Light District]]</li> </ul>\ <<else>>\ <h1><<link "South East Checkpoint">><<popup "South East Checkpoint Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "South East Checkpoint Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Wave to Pistol as you walk by.|Graveyard Transition]]</li> <li> [[Back off.|Red Light District]]</li> </ul>\ <</if>>\<p>This checkpoint felt so out of place here, right on the border of the Red Light District. The external walls, lined as they were with buildings, yeilded to a small metal gate. Big enough it'd take a lot of effort to close, small enough that you could fit no more than two horses through side-by-side. Beyond it, you could see cracked asphalt roads leading off into the wastes towards the massive relics to the South.</p> <p>Guarding this gate (to some extent) was a militia guy, easily identified as such by the fatigues he was wearing and the massive rifle at his side. He didn't exactly cut an intimidating figure, though. He was sat on a metal folding chair, legs crossed, with a stack of reading material on the table next to him. Mostly old Playboy magazines and a paperback or two. He was thumbing through a colourful array of nude women, so engrossed in //reading the articles// that he barely even acknowledged your presence. A big, wide brimmed hat was tilted low over his face to shield him from the sun.</p><h1><<link "Skid Row">><<popup "Skid Row Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<if not $visited.includes("Skid Row")>><<include "Skid Row Description">><<set $visited.push("Skid Row")>><<else>><<include "Skid Row Description Short">><</if>><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Enter the clinic.|Clinic Hub]]</li> <li> [[Enter the warehouse.|Abandoned Warehouse]]</li> <li> [[Venture West.|Derelict Block Hub]]</li> <li> [[Head up to The Stacks.|The Stacks]]</li> </ul>\<p>The main hub of Skid Row wasn't exactly a bustling urban metropolis. The unpaved square in the center was ash trod down by decades of foot traffic, tapering into narrow streets to the East and West as shoddy buildings encroached upon its space. They were a mess of corrugated metal, scrap bricks, and stucco all built up on top of each other. Barely enough space was left for an alleyway between any two constructs, with most walls either shared or built within inches of each other. Like the builders wanted to use up every last scrap of space. There was a strange history to these buildings, like they'd been hasty but careful constructions many decades ago and were frozen in a state of half-decay. On the streets, a scant few people in shabby knits and raw denim walked by with heads down.</p> <p>The Signal Hill Free Clinic was a squat, red brick building towards the South of the main square, flanked on either side by two-storey structures. Across it, on the North side of the square, the centerpiece of the area- a three-storey blocky warehouse made of concrete panels, its front (or what was probably the back, many decades ago) featuring three loading docks whose doors had long since been removed. The inside looked vast, dark, and mostly empty. Above the doors, there was a painted logo for some company which had long since faded in the sun- and in front of it, emblazoned in bright orange and yellow, was a simplified painting of a streetlamp.</p> <p>To the East, the narrow ash road gave way to cobble and brick steps leading around a bend and up further into the city, towards The Stacks. To the West, it snaked labyrinth-like further into the web of dense, ramshackle buildings.</p><p>Skid Row was a mass of buildings constructed almost on top of each other. Its winding ash-trod paths were populated only by a scant few people keeping their heads down as they hurried about their business. On the North side of the main square was the centerpice of the area- a three-storey warehouse from the old world, now abandoned, its loading dock doors sitting open. Across from it was the Signal Hill Free Clinic, a squat and nondescript brick building. If you were to carry on to the West, you could walk infinitely into the maze-like unplanned architecture of the Row.</p><<if $leads.includes("checkup")>>\ <<include "Checkup Intro">>\ <<else>>\ <h1><<link "Signal Hill Free Clinic">><<popup "Clinic Hub Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<if not $visited.includes("Clinic Hub")>><<include "Clinic Hub Description">><<set $visited.push("Clinic Hub")>><<else>><<include "Clinic Hub Description Short">><</if>><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Approach the desk.|Joyette]]</li> <li> [[Step behind the curtain.|Clinic Room]]</li> <li> [[Try knocking on the back door.|Clinic Door]]</li> <li> [[Leave the clinic.|Skid Row]]</li> </ul>\ <</if>>\<p>The clinic's main room was built up on a well-worn concrete floor, with peeling plaster walls. Three little cubbies off to the side were covered up with blue curtains to give some privacy to the folks inside, one of which was currently reserved for you. Behind the others, you could hear the beeping of the strange, inhuman machines keeping track of their inhabitants' vitals. On the far wall was a cabinet of metal and glass keeping hundreds of bottles of medications locked away from eager patients. Several metal folding chairs were up against the wall next to it, with a closed and locked doorway labeled "OFFICES" in black paint. The door outside was rigged with a bell to go off whenever a patient entered, although such a thing seemed unnecessary. There was a desk right across from it, with rows of old filing cabinets lined up behind.</p> <p>Sitting at the desk was Joyette, in front of what looked like some kind of old television that was switched off and a powder-blue typewriter. You'd estimate she was about 40- her dark skin was mostly unmarred by age, but the deep crows feet that spread out from her eyes hinted at a life lived. Her head was hidden under a bright orange-and-blue-patterned headscarf, with only a few stray locs hanging out the front over her thick rimmed glasses. She didn't look up from her typing for even a moment as you entered the room.</p><p>The clinic was an austere place, peeling plaster walls and concrete floors. There were three little cordoned off cubbies to the side for patients, across from a massive cabinet full of tinctures and pills. Sitting at a desk in the back corner, typing away on a powder blue typewriter, was Joyette. She didn't seem particularly interested in you. Beside her, a door labelled "OFFICES" led further into the building.</p><h1><<link "Clinic Bed">><<popup "Clinic Room Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if $temp == "wakeup">>\ <p>Still shaky on your feet, you tried to get your bearings. For the foreseeable future, this was going to be your home. So you should probably get used to it.</p> <p>The room was sterile, white, with a floor made of concrete that's been smoothed over by years of walking. The plaster walls were undecorated, and the curtain that separated you from the rest of the clinic let all the sound from outside in. Apart from the cot in the corner, the only furniture was a simple metal table<<if $altar is true>> you had turned into an altar<</if>> and a busted up old locker.</p> <<else>>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Clinic Room Description">> <</if>>\ <</if>>\ <<unset $temp>>\ <ul>\ <<if $identity.includes("devotee")>>\ <<if $hasaltar is true>>\ <li> [[Go to your altar.|Altar]]</li> <<else>>\ <li> [[Inspect the table.|Altar Setup]]</li> <</if>>\ <</if>>\ <<if $apartmentinventory.has("Record Player")>>\ <li> [[Turn on the record player.|Record Player]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[Get some rest.|Sleep]]</li> <li> [[Check out the locker.|Wardrobe]]</li> <li> [[Leave the room.|Clinic Hub]]</li> </ul>\ <<set $apartment to passage()>>\<p>You pulled back the blue curtain and stepped into your little cubby, closing it behind you to get some modicum of privacy.</p> <p>The room was sterile, white, with a floor made of concrete that's been smoothed over by years of walking. The plaster walls were undecorated, and the curtain that separated you from the rest of the clinic let all the sound from outside in. Apart from the cot in the corner, the only furniture was a simple metal table<<if $altar is true>> you had turned into an altar<</if>> and a busted up old locker.<<if $apartmentinventory.has("Record Player")>> You've got your record player set up in the corner on the floor- a rather depressing sight, but y'know. The records work just fine there.<</if>></p><<if $playedleads.includes("consultation")>>\ <p>You approached the closed door and almost manged a knock before Joyette noticed you had wandered over there. "I'm sorry, but Dr. Zhao is a little busy right now. I'm right here if you need anything."</p> * [[Leave.|Clinic Hub]] <<else>>\ <p>The door into the office was shut, but from the muffled sound of piano music behind it, you knew Doc was in there. But to knock or not to knock...</p> * [[Knock.|Consultation]] * [[No, you've got other stuff to do first.|Clinic Hub]] <</if>>\<p>This wasn't exactly a state of the art operating theater. It was a small room, big enough for two doctors to work on the patient at the same time. The tools were rudimentary, the equipment was all sanitized in a big bucket of alcohol, and the IV was fed from a resealable plastic bag. It was free, though.</p><<include "Operating Room">> <p>You allowed yourself to be laid back on the table and your hand to be lifted up onto a clean operating surface. "Unfortunately, I don't have anything that can knock you out. It would be far too unsafe." Doc's voice was grim. "I'm afraid the best I can do is laughing gas."</p> <<if $identity.includes("medic")>>\ <p>"Oh, shit. Okay." You'd encountered nitrous in your work before, back up North. Some of the places you worked used it as a sort of anaesthetic. Wasn't as good as a systemic one, but it was patient-led and far safer than the alternative.</p> <<elseif $identity.includes("hedonist")>>\ <p>Oh //hell// yeah. He had nitrous here? How had you not known he had nitrous here? Maybe you could buy some off of him, find some people who were less square to enjoy it with.</p> <<else>>\ <p>"What's laughing gas?"</p> <</if>>\ <p>Doc turned around, stepping out of your vision, and a hissing sound rang out through the room. When he faced you again, he was holding a thick, black rubber balloon by the neck, half full of some kind of gas. "Just inhale this, as much as you feel comfortable, and hold it for a moment. Then make sure you exhale back into it. Inhale whenever you can feel the pain."</p> <p>"You're giving me drugs, Doc? How kind." He rolled his eyes at you.</p> * [[And then the operation starts.|Operating Room Operation]]<p>The surgery was fucking painful. Even through the haze of the gas, you could feel every stab of a needle and every cut of the knife. But in your drugged up state, you barely cared. Your mind was elsewhere. The lights above you were so bright, and they swirled in your vison, and you were sinking into your pillow further and further and rising up into the cieling. Were you still awake? Jesus.</p> <p>Eventually, Doc wrapped up your wound and left you to recover and sober up, under close monitoring. But the operation was successful. And you were back to health. Or at least, some approximation of health.</p> * [[Time to head back out on your journey.|Clinic Hub]] <<set $needsfirstaid = false>>\ <<unset $firstaid>>\ <<SetFlag "ReattachedFinger">>\ <<dropall $altar "Pinky Finger">>\ <<dropall $pocket "Pinky Finger">>\<h1><<link "Abandoned Warehouse">><<popup "Abandoned Warehouse Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Abandoned Warehouse Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <<if $pissedoffdruggies isnot true>>\ <li> [[Approach the fire.|Druggies]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[Leave.|Skid Row]]</li> </ul>\<p>The warehouse was clearly an old construction, must have been from before everything went to shit. Judging by the awkward placement of the various buildings around it, it seemed to have pre-existed everything, being swallowed by the sprawl of the city when space became a concern.</p> <p>Sets of improvised cinderblock stairs led up to the garage doors, shifting under your weight as you stepped into the staging area. It was dark as the grave in there, the hazy sunlight only barely making its way into the gaping maw of the doorways. Looked like a pretty typical unloading dock inside, not that you'd really know. Wasn't much cargo hanging around inside, but there was a big ol' forklift with the tires long since stolen and a bunch of old woods skids rotting in a pile in the corner.</p> <p>The only sign of life in here was a warm red light emanating from the back corner. It looked like there were people sitting around there.</p><p>The warehouse was ancient- swallowed by the sprawl of the city, but pre-existing it all. Sets of cinderblock stairs let up into the garage doors. The whole place was dark and dingy, empty of life save for a fire in the back corner where a couple people were sitting.</p><h1><<link "Derelict Block">><<popup "Derelict Block Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Derelict Block Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Check out "Threadz."|Threadz]]</li> <li> [[Approach the apartment building.|Slum Motel]]</li> <li> [[Head back.|Skid Row]]</li> </ul>\<p>Heading West, you found yourself entering a sort of maze. The streets grew closer together and the buildings grew further apart, until it was hard to tell what was alley and what was road. People sat with their legs dangling from second storey windows and on rocking chairs on porches, watching you as you passed through. Finally, the choking density of the city opened up once again into a larger street. Below your feet, ash and gravel made way to cracked concrete.</p> <p>The buildings here struck you as odd. They were brick, but not the same sort of reclaimed brickwork as the rest of the Row. Instead, the buildings on either side of the street here looked practically ancient, worn red brick in even lines all from the same source. The roof was what sold it, though- metal panels with regular ridges and fancy corners, clearly made to sit atop a nondescript building like these. This was old world stuff.</p> <p>And it looked like these buildings were being used for their intended purposes, too. Signs hung above the doorways and in windows, advertising grocers and tailors and butchers. The ones that weren't boarded over, at least. One of them caught your eye- boards covered the window, which were spray painted with the word "THREADZ" in bright red. The door was held ajar by a large rock.</p> <p>Just beyond this little complex, a larger building rose above the squat marketplace. It was a big stucco and concrete thing, a real eyesore, two storeys and wide across with a front dotted with individual doors and windows. Not commercial. Some kind of lodging house.</p><p>The maze of Skid Row became harder to parse the further in you got, until the streets widened out again into something oddlyh comprehensible. The buildings arranged on either side of this street were ancient red brick, old world things with big windows and flat, nondescript roofs. Inside were butchers, tailors, grocers, and the suspicious clothing outlet "THREADZ." At the end of the street, there was a big conrete and stucco building covered in doors- some kind of apartment building.</p><h1><<link "Threadz Description">><<popup "Threadz Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Threadz Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <li> [[Talk to the shopkeeper.|Roach]]</li> <li> [[Buy some clothes.|Threadz Store]]</li> <li> [[Leave.|Derelict Block Hub]]</li> </ul><p>Kicking aside the door and stepping into the little shop, your first impression wasn't great. The place was dark, dingy, ancient looking. With all the windows boarded up, the only sources of light were an oil lamp in a display table near the center of the room and a crack in the boards illuminating a whole mansion's worth of floating dust.</p> <p>Despite its drab appearance, this was certainly a clothing store. There was clothing, for one. One or two metal racks held an assortment of hangers, most of which were strung up with garments in linen and cotton and the occasional synthetic. Apart from that, though, the whole room was notably empty. Uncomfortably empty. Everything was situated right in the center, with only debris and the remnants of old store shelves scattered around.</p> <p>As you entered, you apparently caught the attention of the shopkeeper, who had been obscured behind that display table where she had been seated on the tile floor. She let out a yelp and scrambled to her feet, staring at you with wide eyes like an owl. Her hair was a mousy brown and hadn't been washed in years, almost standing on end around her freckled face. She had a petite frame, though you could barely see it, as she was absolutely swimming in an unbleached linen dress. "Hello! Customer! Welcome!"</p>The store was dark, dingy, ancient looking. Cracks in the window boards and a single oil lamp illuminated... mostly dust, but a couple racks of clothing too. Other than that, a vast empty space. The mousy shopkeeper stood idly by, excitedly waiting for you to make a purchase.</p><h1><<link "Apartment Building">><<popup "Slum Motel Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Slum Motel Description">><</if>> <ul>\ <<if $apartments.includes("slum")>>\ <li> [[Enter your apartment.|Slum Apartment]]</li> <</if>>\ <<if $chapter gte 2>>\ <li> [[Enter the office.|Slum Apartment Office]]</li> <</if>>\ <li> [[Nothing much to see here.|Derelict Block Hub]]</li> </ul>\<p>Upon closer inspection, it became clear that this place was some kind of apartment complex. Lights were flickering inside some of the rooms, and through a set of glass doors on the left of the lower floor that were reinforced with metal bars. A sign was set up next to those doors, a wooden thing with stencilled letters reading <<if $chapter == 1>>NO VACANCIES.<<else>>VACANCIES. Part of the sign was covered up with a metal flap on a hinge- presumably the part that read "NO." Smart.<</if>> This must be the office where this place was run from.</p> <<if $chapter gte 2>>\ <<if not $apartments.includes("slum")>>\ <p>The important thing about that sign, though, was the word that //wasn't// hidden. There were vacancies here! If you could scrounge up some cash, you could maybe get one of these apartments. Score.</p> <</if>>\ <</if>>\<h1><<link "Your Apartment">><<popup "Slum Apartment Description">><</link>></h1>\ <<if settings.descriptions == true>><<include "Slum Apartment Description">><</if>> <<set $apartment to passage()>>\ * [[A link, in case you glitch your way here.|Slum Motel]]<p>The apartment you'd rented was one of the worst you'd ever stayed in, but for this part of town, probably a luxury joint. Light spilling in through the front window illuminated not only the furniture but also swirling ash and dust suspended in the air. It was maybe 150 square feet, max. A queen-sized mattress on a simple metal bed frame was shoved into the corner under the window, with a bedside table next to it sporting a well-used oil lamp. On the other side, there was a door into a small but functional bathroom and a set of counters and cabinets approximating a kitchen.</p> <p>This place wasn't lacking in a little luxury, though. There was an overstuffed loveseat, all worn and patched but comfy nonetheless, against the wall. Across from it was a side table <<if $altarsetup == false>>that could maybe be used to hold a television, if only you could afford it (and if only this place had electricity.) <<else>>that held your makeshift altar. <</if>>There was even an icebox in the kitchen, an old world thing that would hold the cold in well. A little slice of heaven in the Row.</p><p>Pushing open one of the doors, you stepped inside the office. It was small, probably no bigger than the biggest suite they offered, but it didn't look like it needed more space. The place was well lit by a number of oil lamps, illuminating a large metal desk, a large set of filing cabinets, and a door into a maintenance closet.</p> <p>Sitting behind the desk, flipping through a naughty zine, was a guy with greasy hair and an even worse goatee. He was dressed up in some fascimile of nice clothing, a cheap suit jacket covered in patches over a stained t-shirt. When you walked in, he looked up at you, not even bothering to hide the spicy photo on the front of the zine in his hands. "What can I help ya with, <<if $player.gender == "woman">>miss?<<else>>bud?<</if>>"</p> <ul>\ <li> [[“Actually, it's nothing. I'm gonna go.”|Slum Motel]]</li> </ul>\<<widget "storereset">> /* DROP EVERYTHING FROM EVERY STORE */ <<dropall $threadz>> <<dropall $infatuations>> <<dropall $tradingco>> <<dropall $darlings>> <<dropall $ricky>> <<dropall $rosebar>> <<dropall $chargebar>> <<unmerge $pace $musiclist>> /* REMOVE DUPLICATES FROM EVERY ITEM LIST */ <<unmerge $handmade $outfit>> <<unmerge $handmade $wardrobe>> <<unmerge $practical $outfit>> <<unmerge $practical $wardrobe>> <<unmerge $punk $outfit>> <<unmerge $punk $wardrobe>> <<unmerge $armoured $outfit>> <<unmerge $armoured $wardrobe>> <<unmerge $luxury $outfit>> <<unmerge $luxury $wardrobe>> <<unmerge $fetish $outfit>> <<unmerge $fetish $wardrobe>> /* ADD RANDOM SELECTION TO EVERY STORE */ /* THREADZ */ <<set _threadz = []>> <<set _threadz1 = []>> <<for _item, _amount range $handmade.table>> <<run _threadz.push(_item)>> <</for>> <<for _i to 0; _i lt 10; _i++>> <<set _threadz1.push(_threadz.random())>> <</for>> <<for _item range _threadz1>> <<pickup $threadz _item 1>> <</for>> /* INFATUATIONS */ <<set _infatuations = []>> <<set _infatuations1 = []>> <<for _item, _amount range $fetish.table>> <<run _infatuations.push(_item)>> <</for>> <h1>"""---""" <<link "CHARGE ALL">><<spendwealth 1>><<set _batteries = $pocket.count("Empty Battery")>><<drop $pocket "Empty Battery" _batteries>><<pickup $pocket "Charged Battery" _batteries>><<goto "Charge Bar Sit">><</link>> """---"""</h1>\ <</if>>\ <h1>"""---""" [[DON'T CHARGE|Charge Bar Sit]] """---"""</h1>\ <<elseif $pocket.count("Empty Battery") lte 5>>\ <h1>Would you like to charge all of
